desc: This lightly aromatic wine conveys ripe red apple, pear, and star fruit. The fruit flavors are centered in a ball in the middle, offering plenty of appeal if not much complexity.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Angove's 2001 Classic Reserve Pinot Noir (South Australia)
desc: This Pinot has sturdy red fruit going for it, plus a smooth mouthfeel and medium body. But it also had a strange powdery accent to it that reminded me somewhat of instant iced tea—sure, it gave the wine a more interesting texture, but the flavor I could have done without. - D.M.

wine_name: Grassini 2015 Sauvignon Blanc (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)
desc: Fresh and inviting on the nose, this bottling shows sweet white flowers, Asian pear, yellow-grapefruit rind and lemon blossoms on the nose. Acidity explodes onto the palate, where a grassy, grapefruit-pith-driven tension rides into a rounded midpalate full of pear, nectarine and honeydew flavors.
Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Honeysuckle and tropical fruit aromas lead the way on this bright, tangy white from the shores of Lake Garda. The juicy palate offers white peach and green melon before a white almond finish.
Tropical fruit and crushed tomato vine aromas lift out of the glass. On the simple palate, fresh acidity lifts pineapple and a suggestion of grapefruit.

wine_name: Housley's Century Oak 2013 Judy's Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Lodi)
desc: This full-bodied wine has earthy, woodsy aromas, ripe and mature fruit flavors and a broad, almost soft texture. It's very mouth-filling and smooth, and will please people who like a little rusticity in their wines.

wine_name: Tenuta Cocci Grifoni 2004 Podere Colle Vecchio  (Offida Pecorino)
desc: Another interesting wine made from an obscure indigenous grape, this white is very fragrant and rich with tones of grapefruit, yellow flowers, white powder, pear and melon. It has strong and attractive mineral characteristics in the mouth and ends on a bitter note.
Bright and fruity, this is a crisp, herbal wine. From the Bougrier family estate it is perfumed, creamy and offers refreshing acidity, citrus and hints of apricots. The wine is ready to drink.

Grown in the sandy soil of Tejo, far from the granite of northern Portugal, this Alvarinho is broad but light, and attractively perfumed. It has light tannins, lime and apricot fruit and a zesty aftertaste. Drink now.

wine_name: Domaine D'en Ségur 2015 Sauvignon Blanc (Côtes du Tarn)
desc: This is a bright style of Sauvignon Blanc with pear and red-apple acidity and an attractive hint of lime juice. With a tangy aftertaste, it is light, packed with fruitiness and ready to drink.
Appellation: Côtes du Tarn, Southwest France, France

desc: An inaugural release from veteran Napa winemaker Wayne Donaldson. The wine is a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Syrah, and shows the modern signature of ripe, smooth tannins and rich blackberry, cassis, chocolate and cedar flavors. Delicious now, it should hang in there for six years.

In a recent series of entry-level Madeiras, this was a standout, offering excellent complexity and richness at a reasonable price. Nuts, toffee and dried fruit aromas and flavors swirl together, balancing moderate sweetness with harmonious acids. Long on the finish.

wine_name: Keller Estate 2007 Precioso Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
desc: A dazzlingly good Pinot Noir. Hard to exaggerate the precision of flavor and structure. Shows the massively ripe character of the vintage, with a starburst of raspberries, cherries, cola, minerals and spices, while the acidity and tannins are just about perfect. This crowd pleaser is just extraordinary now, and should develop in the bottle over the next six years.

wine_name: Gorman 2010 Behind the Black Curtain Reserve Syrah (Red Mountain)
desc: This pure Syrah—the first reserve Syrah from Gorman—pulls out all the stops. It's a tannic, bold, earthy and powerful wine that's loaded with black fruits. Aged for 20 months in 100% new French oak, it takes the wood in stride, adding Red Mountain minerality to the mix.
Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Geyser Peak 2013 Pluto's Fury Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
desc: This is a softly layered wine with just the right amount of tension to give credence to a lifted minerality, accented by well-crafted clove and baked strawberry. The finish is spicy in more clove and nutmeg.
Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US

desc: This is a brand, created in the 19th century that had almost disappeared until rescued in the last decade. This Vintage comes from 40 to 60-year-old vines in the Douro Superior, giving a wine with soft tannins and great fruit concentration. It is floral from the Touriga Nacional with fine acidity to balance the ripe, sweet fruit. Drink from 2025.

wine_name: Four Sons 2002 Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)
desc: There's lots of rich varietal character in this fresh wine. It's full-bodied and dry, with black currant and cherry flavors and a hit of oak. Finishes with firm tannins, but best consumed now.
Appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US

wine_name: Talisman 2013 Adastra Vineyard Pinot Noir (Los Carneros)
desc: Adastra is an organically farmed vineyard and the wine shows an earthy profile that's substantial and defining. Full bodied and ripe, it rides a tension of acidity that provides freshness, seasoned in tart cherry and pomegranate.

wine_name: Château de la Vieille Tour 2017  Bordeaux Supérieur
desc: This wine has been overextracted giving a dry and bitter character. However, it has some black fruits and should come together with time. Drink from 2021.

Poised and polished, this opens with aromas of mature plum, baking spice, menthol and a whiff of new leather. The ripe but restrained palate shows structure and elegance, offering mature black cherry, pomegranate, star anise, and chopped herb. Tightly wound, fine-grained tannins proved the framework.

wine_name: Thomas Fogarty 2016 Razorback Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)
desc: Intriguing aromas of dark raspberry, damp thyme, white pepper, cola, slate and pine needle make for a very compelling entry to this bottling. There is great freshness and energy to the sip, where orange rind, raspberry and pomegranate flavors make for a refreshingly light sip.
Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Here's a dense but easygoing Nero d'Avola with sensations of blue flower, sweet black cherry, blueberry extract, clove and cinnamon. The soft, round palate offers juicy fruit, with a succulent blackberry finish.

wine_name: Domaines Barons de Rothschild (Lafite) 2002 Los Vascos Cabernet Sauvignon (Colchagua Valley)
desc: Soft, thick and chewy. Red plums and raspberries define the palate, which is backed by a modest, oaky finish. A bit lactic and plump, but tasty.

A first-class Zin that shows classic mountain character, at a very nice price. Dry and rich in tannins, it's explosive in briary, brambly wild berries, currants, dark chocolate and pepper, with a touch of raisins. Just delicious.
Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US

wine_name: Gary Farrell 2006 Collins Vineyard Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)
desc: This is a really good Zinfandel. It shows the exuberant, lusty quality of the variety, with wild blackberry, mulberry, tobacco and spice flavors that have a briary mouthfeel. But it brings a classic structure and elegance. Fine now, and the refined tannins suggest ageability through 2012.
Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US

desc: This is a gem, with lots of up-front toast. A typical  structured year for Champagne, this has clean, round fruit, but retains good acid, providing firm support and longer-term aging potential than the '95. It floats into a pleasing, vanilla cream and toast finish.

This blend of Zweigelt, Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon is firmly structured. In fact, it's more a structural wine than a flavorful one, although it does boast scents of tar and cooked plum and modest, fruity notes on the palate. Drink it over the next few years before the fruit fades. Imported by Vin Divino.

wine_name: Caves Aliança 2004 Quinta das Baceladas Red (Bairrada)
desc: A rare Portuguese Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon blend, made with the involvement of Bordeaux winemaker Pascal Chatonnet, working with Caves Aliança's winemaker Francisco Antunes. Does it work? Yes, as a delicious curiosity. There is no connection with Portugal, but there is smooth new wood, and some pepper from alcohol. Then tannins are dry, the fruit is very ripe and very rich.

wine_name: Petrified Forest Vineyards 2015 Totem Ridge Merlot (Knights Valley)
desc: Brawny and brooding in black and red berry, this is a well-integrated, cohesive and harmonious wine, aged 18 months in French oak. The tannins are soft and supple and the acidity high toned, allowing room for herbal elements to shine within the fruit.

Crisp and nice Cava with good balance, clean apple, dusty spices and pithy lemon. Fold it all together on the nose, palate and finish and you wind up with a well-made, attractive, easy-to-sip bubbly with some polish. Textbook everyday Cava.
Tomato-vine, gooseberry and elder-flower aromas lift out of the glass. The racy palate shows pineapple, green melon and a hint of bell pepper alongside bright acidity.
Appellation: Friuli Colli Orientali, Northeastern Italy, Italy

desc: Earthy—with some aromas and flavors reminiscent of damp clay—but shows pleasant notes of sourdough, vanilla and cream as well, gliding gently into a citrusy palate and buttery, slightly soft finish. Drink now.
There's a slight acrid tinge to the primarily woody nose and the fruit on the palate is tart and thin. Pleasant leathery and dried-spice notes partially redeem it.

wine_name: Castillo de Monjardin 1999 Reserva - Barrel Fermented Chardonnay (Navarra)
desc: Yellow in color and well oaked, with creamy, waxy aromas that convey richness. Flavors of honey, apple and lemon curd, and then an average, clean finish come later. Plenty of size and power are on display; if only the wine were more complex and subtle.

wine_name: Paul Hobbs 2009 Beckstoffer To Kalon Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)
desc: This is a pinnacle of the modern style of winemaking in Napa Valley. The tannins are strong but not aggressive. The acidity is just enough to provide balance for the tremendously rich blackberry, black currant, Kahlua and olive flavors. The oak is powerful, but the wine wears it easily. The finish is thoroughly dry, long and spicy. And although the alcohol is high, it's not impossible. You can drink it now, although the tannins could benefit from 6–8 years in the cellar.

Truffle, new leather, pressed blue flower, menthol and a whiff of game lead the way. The aromas carry over to the ripe, full-bodied palate along with fleshy black cherry, steeped prune, cinnamon and star anise. Buffed tannins provide the framework. It's already accessible but will maintain well for the next several years. Drink through 2023.
This is an easygoing Pinot Noir with supple tannins and a soft mouthfeel. Cherry and vanilla flavors are inviting, with just a bit of a herbal note to add freshness. Drink now.

wine_name: Château Bois de Rolland 2009  Bordeaux Supérieur
desc: This is smooth and lush, with its tannins softened by ripe berry fruit and a strong presence of spicy wood. It has weight, density and, on the finish, fruitiness.
Thanks to its low price tag, this is the kind of wine you can pack for an outdoor picnic or drink at a family barbecue. It's fresh, clean and characterized by white cherry and cassis.
Crisp and refreshing, it delivers honeysuckle, ripe yellow peach, pink grapefruit and lemon-lime sensations. Energizing minerality and crisp acidity give a pristine finish.

There's a nice brambly character to this wine, with assertive savory herbs and fresh mint sprigs jazzing up the ripe berry-fruit core. Medium weight with a softly creamy texture and a vanilla-infused finish.

wine_name: Casa Silva 2010 Reserva Cabernet Sauvignon (Colchagua Valley)
desc: The nose is vibrant and a bit feral, with aromas of red plum, cherry, red currant and herb. It feels lively, with raspberry, cherry and herbal plum flavors. The finish is juicy.
Nice price, clean wine, and probably unoaked. However, the fruit is kind of thin and watery.

Dark and inky, this is a burly wine, jammy to the core. Floral aromas meet spicy leather and white pepper alongside a strong streak of rosemary, recalling roast lamb, a pairing with which it would succeed.

wine_name: Cadence 2009 Bel Canto Cara Mia Vineyard Red (Red Mountain)
desc: This could be labeled as Cabernet Franc, since it comprises 80% of the blend. The youthful lightness of the estate-grown grapes seems to lift the naturally tannic nature of the variety. It's clean and balanced, and it comes with an herbal underpinning. This is best for near-term drinking.
Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Novelty Hill 2009 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))
desc: This tight, young Syrah has a succinct core of blueberry and raspberry flavors, which are wrapped in a mix of herb, earth and green tea. The tannins are just slightly bitter, but all in balance, and that bitterness is not at all unpleasant.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: An excellent effort, La Roubine's 2004 Gigondas takes blackberry and pepper notes and combines them in a lovely bouquet that's more than the sum of its parts. There's a lushly textured, creamy mouthfeel that makes for even more hedonistic delight. Like a repeating decimal, it's long on the finish. Drink now–2012, maybe longer.

wine_name: Companhia das Quintas 2015 Portal da Vinha Red (Alentejano)
desc: This is a young, fruity wine made for early drinking. With bright acidity, soft tannins and forward red fruit, it's easy-drinking and ready now.

Elegant aromas of exotic strawberry, charred oak and loamy earth show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is clean and quite textural, with strong acid carrying red-fruit and cinnamon-spice flavors.
Appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US

wine_name: Kontos 2013 Summit View Vineyard Malbec (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
desc: Coming from an up-and-coming region of the valley, this wine is direct in its appeal, with opulent aromas of dark plum, grape gummy, peppery spices and an herbal top note. The flavors are broad and pure, showing a deft touch. Coffee flavors linger on the finish.
Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Shows a briary, toughly tensile quality to its aromas, along with hints of beet and meatiness, while the flavors tend more toward black cherries and crushed stone. Round and full in the mouth, with supple tannins on the finish.

wine_name: Ruston 2002 La Maestra Red Wine Red (St. Helena)
desc: A Cabernet-based Bordeaux blend, and what a nice wine it is. Rich in cherry, raspberry, cassis and mocha flavors, but saved from simple fruit overload by good acidity and finely ground, though sizable, tannins. Has the structure to age though 2015.

wine_name: Casas del Bosque 2019 Pinot Noir Rosé (Casablanca Valley)
desc: Citrus peel aromas are oily and modest, while this rosé of Pinot Noir is highly citric and skins-driven in terms of feel. Short, racy tangerine flavors are bold but limited, while this is basic on the finish.

Fragrant, full bodied and boasting great finesse, this delicious Barolo hits all the right buttons. It opens with enticing aromas of woodland berry, rose, camphor, botanical herb and exotic spice while the elegantly structured palate doles out juicy red cherry, crushed raspberry, licorice and cinnamon. Firm, fine-grained tannins and fresh acidity keep it impeccably balanced. It's already tempting but hold for even more complexity. Drink 2024–2046.

Self-proclaimed to be the only Sagrantino in the Napa Valley (which is probably true), this wine displays varietal character in its smoky leather and its fruit characteristics trafficking in tart cranberry, orange and black cherry. It is light and subtle.

wine_name: Wines of Illyria 2012 Illyrian Traditional Vranac (Bosnia and Herzegovina)
desc: Made from Vranac, an ancient variety from Illyria, now Bosnia and Herzegovina, this garnet wine has aromas of vanilla, toast, violet and toasted hazelnut. On the palate there are flavors of black currant, black raspberry, plum and elderberry.
Appellation: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bosnia and Herzegovina

wine_name: Roux Père et Fils 2015 Les Murgers des Denys de Chien Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)
desc: While this wine is rich, its tight texture brings out the minerality. Yellow fruits and toast are balanced with zingy acidity for a wine that will need time to broaden out. Drink from 2021.
Designation: Les Murgers des Denys de Chien Premier Cru

wine_name: Canoe Ridge 2018 The Expedition Chardonnay (Horse Heaven Hills)
desc: Aromas of vanilla, pear, butter and spice lead to full-bodied vanilla and apple flavors. The barrel notes play a significant role, but there's still a lot to like.
Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: You'll appreciate the elegant approach of this luminous rosé made from the Montepulciano grape and its friendly aromas of small berry and red rose. The wine offers nice smoothness and persistency that is driven by bursting fresh berry flavors.
Appellation: Montepulciano d'Abruzzo Cerasuolo, Central Italy, Italy

wine_name: Giesen 2014 Single Vineyard Selection Waihopai Pinot Noir (Marlborough)
desc: One of Giesen's top single-vineyard wines, this is elegant and silky. Aromas of red berries, flowers, coffee grounds and cinnamon sticks are wrapped in a savory, dried leaf core. Light to medium in body, everything is in balance, from the delicate acidity and satiny tannins to the juicy, tart red fruit and floral flavors. Drink now–2026.

This Riserva Barbaresco scored in the “excellent” range because it is at drinking peak now. The wine is soft and generous and thickly padded with aromas of sweet cherry, almond marzipan, vanilla, red licorice, apple skin, black slate and smoke. It exhibits a remarkable balance between modern and traditional styles. Drink now.

Aromas of French oak, coconut, dark-skinned fruit and blue flower lead the way. Linear and firmly structured, the full-bodied palate offers ripe Marasca cherry, vanilla and toasted hazelnut alongside taut close-grained tannins. Drink after 2024–2031.
The price is good and the wine is totally dry. This is a rugged, country-style wine that's so low in fruit, the alcohol, which is actually pretty low, dominates.

wine_name: Ryan Patrick 2015 Olsen Brothers Vineyard Riesling (Yakima Valley)
desc: Lime, slate and floral aromas lead to an off-dry palate, with generous amounts of stone-fruit flavors. Floral notes persist on the finish.
Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Carmel 2012 Single Vineyard Kayoumi Vineyard White Riesling (Galilee)
desc: This medium-straw colored wine has a nose of lemon and tomato leaf. Flavors of lemon, orange, baking bread and a light cottony feel are ultimately brightened by a final wash of acidity.

wine_name: Robert Weil 2009 Kiedrich Turmberg Trocken Riesling (Rheingau)
desc: Starts off with struck flint and passion fruit, but develops almost sweaty notes that make it something of a challenge. It's light and lively, just too funky to rate higher.

wine_name: La Purísima 2007 Old Hands Organically Grown Monastrell (Yecla)
desc: Light and rather floral for a Monastrell, with cassis, cherry and leather aromas. It's mildly brambly and not as deep as the 2006 version. Tastes like blackberry and leather, while the tannic grab is strapping. Finishes with a hint of spice and herbs, but also a pinch of bitterness.

wine_name: Casa de Vilacetinho 2017 Superior Avesso-Loureiro White (Vinho Verde)
desc: Full of great fruits, this is a rich and ripe wine. White stone fruits, layers of juicy acidity and intense citrus and apricot flavors are overlaid with a tangy character, shot through with minerality. Drink this wine from 2019.
This late harvest wine reminds one of lemon grass, cut grass and honeysuckle. It is sweet with a good acid balance along with flavors of lemon meringue pie and lemon curd.
Soft and ripe, this has light tannins, red berry fruit and a round texture. It has a touch of firmness, acidity and good density. Drink now, or age it for 2–3 years.

A plummy, semi-sweet dark red wine that could stand a bit of a chill in the fridge. It has a nice chocolatey edge that would be a good partner with dark chocolate desserts. Finishes clean and with good acidity.

Lusty black-fruit aromas are earthy, oaky and smooth, exemplifying an excellent Ribera del Duero. A palate with pulsing acidity tempers rich flavors of blackberry, chocolate and vanilla. Creamy oak and some fire on the finish guarantee that this will evolve nicely through 2028.
Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain

wine_name: Feudo di Santa Tresa 2010  Cerasuolo di Vittoria Classico
desc: Cerasuolo di Vittoria is one of the most exciting red wines to emerge from southern Italy in recent years. This is made with organic fruit, and it shows bright tones of raspberry and cassis, with some tones of toasted almond and light spice at the back.
Appellation: Cerasuolo di Vittoria Classico, Sicily & Sardinia, Italy

desc: Batailley 2006 has been mainly about tannin from its earliest stages, and this has not yet changed. What has changed is that the tannin isn't by itself any more: black plum fruit is now giving some richness. It does need to age, but the elegance and the balance are coming.

A pale-pink color, this rosé offers extremely faint scents of white flowers, melon rind and orange. The palate is light and breezy, with supersoft red-fruit and citrus flavors. It's easy to drink, with final hints of cranberry and orange zest.

Noceto is a Sierra Foothills' Sangiovese specialist but does a nice job with Barbera as well, this wine being well-integrated, not heavy-handed (13.8%) with a deft balance between acidity and fruit, mostly sweet cherry and blueberry. Very good.
Appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US

desc: This is the essence of fresh, crisp, light Chilean Chardonnay. A very light and well-applied dose of oak supports pear and apple fruit, and the finish is smooth and nicely nutty.
Fruity, filled with succulent cherry, black raspberry and mocha flavors and even blueberries, in a fully dry wine. Soft and gentle texture, long spicy finish.
Appellation: Calaveras County, Sierra Foothills, California, US

wine_name: Pauletts 2009 Stone Cutting No Oak Chardonnay (Clare Valley)
desc: A lean, crisp style of Chardonnay, with citrusy flavors and a touch of honeyed development. Drink it over the next few months.

This has aromas of weedy underbrush, used leather and moist soil. The lean palate is already evolved, suggesting prune, blood orange and the barest hint of roasted coffee bean alongside grainy, fleeting tannins.

This is a multifaceted and tasty drop from two organic vineyards in the Bendigo and Pisa subregions of Central Otago. Fragrant, fruit aromas of grapefruit, lemon, pineapple and lychee are laced with streaks of honey, flint and minerals, showing just a little green veg and herbal nuances. The palate offers zippy acidity, bright fruit, dried herb and chalky minerality, leading to a lemony zing on the finish.
Oaky and spicy, this wine traffics in lemon, lime and tart green apple, a medium-bodied effort of balanced richness and concentration that should do well at the table.
This Pinot Noir rosé has raspberry flavor softened with a touch of caramel and given structure by light tannins. The wine has a ripe feel, down to the warm acidity on the finish.

A lot of Oregon vintners are eager to get on Shea's customer list, and this bottle is as good an example as any why that's the case. A striking mix of cranberry, strawberry, raspberry and marionberry flavors, it also sports a firm seam of stem and earth. The tannins are smooth and polished, with the pleasantly drying mouthfeel of tea.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: A little one-dimensional, but clean and tasty, with bright cherry and cola flavors and some smoky oak. The silky texture and brisk acidity make it food-friendly, especially with something like grilled wild salmon.

Cheerful, light white aromas of citrus—lemon and orange mainly—lead on this white blend from Patras. On the palate, it's refreshing but offers some depth in its lemon and orange muscat flavors. Simple but appealing, and at an excellent price.

wine_name: Loring Wine Company 2006 Shea Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
desc: This is the first wine made from Oregon grapes by this southern California winery. But one can't help but wonder if shipping fruit all the way down the coast might bang it up a bit. For whatever reason, this wine tastes fractured, metallic and chalky. There is a core of black cherry, but it seems surrounded by gun-metal flavors, which stick to the palate and abruptly shut down the finish.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: Generic melon and peach aromas precede a slightly forced and sweet palate with melony flavors and some tail-end bitterness. The finish is creamy and shows vanilla as well as peach and toast notes. Very basic Chardonnay given the price.

Stony and minerally, with some nectarine and citrus scents that develop into grapefruit and stone fruit flavors on the palate. Clean and fresh without being hard or edgy, this is nicely balanced and nicely priced. Imported by Grape Expectations (CA).

This is a full-bodied varietal wine, earthy in aspects of anise and dark chocolate. Blueberry and raspberry flavors mingle around tightly wound tannins and integrated oak, with tart acidity lending lift and lasting freshness.
Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US

wine_name: Peter Lehmann 2001 The Futures Shiraz (Barossa Valley)
desc: What was once a cellar door-only wine finally makes its way Stateside. Fruit is juicy and chewy from palate to finish, dressed up with a hint of barbecue smoke. Nose is super creamy, with plum fruit in a supporting role.

wine_name: Phillips Hill 2013 Oppenlander Vineyard Pinot Noir (Mendocino)
desc: An outstanding example of balance and reserve that doesn't lack in flavor, this wine will pair well with a wide variety of foods. It has a mild color as well as spicy, woodsy aromas due to 35% whole-cluster fermentation. Satisfying flavors resemble a wine-reduction sauce but are dry and crisp.

The oak (25% new French and American) is pleasantly dialed back here allowing the pure notes of plum, cherry, and espresso to shine through. The concentration dips a bit in the middle but it still brings much to enjoy and fits in well at the dinner table.
Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Garofalo 2012 Les Collines Vineyard Viognier (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
desc: Scents and flavors of toasted grain introduce this pretty wine that boasts accents of citrus blossom. Hints of peach skin carry some bite in the back of the mouth. Serve chilled and drink soon.
Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Ancient Oak Cellars 2011 Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)
desc: This offers a pleasing intermix of fruit and spice, from blackberry and plum to Cab-like cassis. Juicy, mouthfilling and structured, it has a finish all about cinnamon and peppercorns.
Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US

wine_name: Jamesport 2011 Chardonnay (North Fork of Long Island)
desc: The scent of apple blossoms perfume this round, richly structured wine, accentuating flavors of apple and pear on the palate. Touches of vanilla and cream add weight and mouthfeel, but the wine finishes crisp with lemony acidity and saline minerality.
Appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US

wine_name: Domaine de la Madone 2008 Le Perreon  (Beaujolais-Villages)
desc: A rich style, with ripe black fruits, touches of fig and firm tannins. For a Villages, this is powerful and dense, with ripe, warm licorice. Acidity comes through finally, giving a lift of freshness but not taking away from the richness.

Pretty, lush and modern, this well-extracted Aglianico del Vulture offers aromas of soft spice, cumin, cinnamon, church incense and candied fruit. Its color is ruby red and lively, and the wine delivers loads of vibrant spice.
Appellation: Aglianico del Vulture, Southern Italy, Italy

wine_name: Château Beynat 2012 Cuvée Léonard  (Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux)
desc: Fresh and fruity, this is already very drinkable. Tannins could soften further, but the bright red fruits and acidity are juicy enough already. The mineral texture and fragrant aftertaste form a balanced combination. This cuvée is selected from plots on the Beynat property.
Appellation: Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France

wine_name: Amayna 2019 Estate Bottled Sauvignon Blanc (Leyda Valley)
desc: Tangy aromas of zesty citrus, sea brine and fresh herbs open this Leyda Valley SB that has emerged as one of Chile's most consistently excellent Sauvignon Blancs. Green-melon, thyme and citrus flavors extend across a clean, stony, acid-driven finish. This was made for seafood dishes dressed in olive oil and lemon juice.

wine_name: Patriarche Père et Fils 2013 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)
desc: Soft and buttery, this wine is smooth and creamy with hints of citrus and a tangy backdrop. With a lightly toasty edge, the wine finishes more tightly than it starts. Drink now.

wine_name: La Val 2011 La Val Sobre Lías Albariño (Rías Baixas)
desc: Oily, briny, waxy aromas reflect aging and extended time on lees, both of which this wine has been through. Piercing acidity keeps things in balance, while oxidized flavors of corn and salted peach finish strong and slightly bitter. This unique style of Albariño is not for everyone.

wine_name: Vignerons de Buxy 2009 Les Chaniots Premier Cru  (Montagny)
desc: Rich and full, the wood and yellow fruit flavors are well integrated with the ripe acidity. Generous as well as elegant, it's a wine to drink now.

Fairly jumpy and foxy on the nose, but underneath you'll find zippy red fruit and gumball sweetness. The palate has a syrupy feel with decent tannins and a pedestrian structure. Tastes sweet, ripe and candied, with mild raisin on the finish.

wine_name: Fox Run 2010 Riesling 10 Lake Dana Vineyard Riesling (Finger Lakes)
desc: Vibrant lemon- and lime-zest notes make this off-dry Riesling brisk and bright. Chalky minerality and a saline tone add depth, and there is a pleasantly bitter lemon-peel note that lingers on the finish.
Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US

desc: Although it tastes a bit on the sweet side, there is no denying the simple freshness and drinkability of this supple, medium-bodied wine. It has light maple-syrup aromas and fresh strawberry flavors.

wine_name: St. Innocent 2016 Freedom Hill Vineyard Pinot Blanc (Willamette Valley)
desc: This delicious, sexy wine impresses with its leesy, textural mouthfeel, its mountain spring freshness, it's crisp lemon and grapefruit flavors, and its underlying minerality. One-quarter was fermented in neutral French oak, the rest in stainless steel. A dash of minty wintergreen trails the finish.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: A little flat and resiny on first take, with a lot of toast and oaky sweetness to the nose. The palate is propped up by citrusy acidity, which adds snap to an otherwise creamy and resiny palate with sweet fruit and spice flavors. Citrusy acids are the key to keeping this oaky wine's head above water.

wine_name: Lieb 2005 Blanc de Blancs Pinot Blanc Brut Sparkling (North Fork of Long Island)
desc: Refreshing and mouthwatering, this wine offers aromas of lemon, citrus and vanilla and an overall clean, elegant palate. Perfect for fresh salads, seafood, poultry.
Designation: Blanc de Blancs Pinot Blanc Brut
Appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US

desc: There's a subdued, easy quality to the bouquet, encompassing aromas of wild berry, ginger, cola and leather. The finish is smooth, fine and slightly chewy.

wine_name: Basel Cellars 2013 Estate Double River Vineyard Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
desc: Bright aromas of smoke, green olive, flowers, roasted meat, toast and huckleberry are followed by ripe full-bodied fruit and barrel flavors. A lightly creamy feel heightens the interest.
Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Domaine Carneros 2004 Le Rêve Blanc de Blancs Sparkling (Carneros)
desc: A superb bubbly, almost entirely comprised of Chardonnay, with 2% Pinot Blanc. It's super-sophisticated, with that elegantly dry, crisp, yeasty feeling associated only with the best sparkling wines. Shows its California origins in the ripe lemon, lime and strawberry flavors that flatter, then pull back into a closure of minerals and spice. A great wine, although the mousse could be finer.
An attractive, spicy and lemony wine, this is off dry in style. Softly textured, hinting at honeyed fruits, the wine is ready to drink.

wine_name: Duca di Saragnano 2016 Governo all'Uso Toscano  (Chianti)
desc: Scorched earth, truffle and dark-skinned fruit aromas emerge on the nose of this wine. The straightforward palate delivers black currant, cedar and vanilla flavors alongside round tannins. Drink soon.

It's nice to find a smooth, full-bodied Cab that's not too tart or tannic, and has enough pleasant, plummy flavors to pair well with burgers, burritos or fried chicken. The flavors have an almost sweet touch of oak, especially on the finish.
This is a delicious, fruity wine, full of black fruits and soft tannins. The wine is forward, and ripe, and demands to be drunk now. Have it with a barbecue.

This ripe wine, with its rich tannins and smooth texture, is delicious. Balanced and soft, it's a ripe blend of Tinta Roriz, Touriga Nacional and Jaen. With blackberry and black-currant flavors, it is fruity. It has no wood aging, although there's some final spice from the fruit. Drink now.

Pure notes of Conference pear appear with the first whiff on the nose and then stay throughout the palate. They are joined by bright and zesty lemon freshness on a concentrated yet very streamlined body. A touch of spritz accentuates that bright lemon and green-pear delicacy even more. Very fresh, very invigorating, it's totally delicious.

Yeasty, reductive funk still dominates the nose and lets none of the fruit shine through—but is nonetheless promising. The mellow palate also showcases yeasty notes, but here they are salty and textural, mixed in with an apple and lemon freshness that draws attention to the concentration on the creamy, textured palate. This is a wine that still needs to come out of its shell, but what lies in wait is racy, zesty and interesting. Drink 2025–2040.
Spicy and nutty, this wine is now ready to drink. It has a soft, toasty character that is lit by smokiness as well as acidity. Drink this ripe, full wine now.

wine_name: Lumos 2013 Temperance Hill Vineyard Gewürztraminer (Eola-Amity Hills)
desc: Very little of this dry, lightly fruity wine is produced. It's fruit more than flower that you'll taste here—melon, peach, and a suggestion of guava. It's fresh and ready to drink right now.
Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: This ripe, forward Cab is extracted in fruit, and made soft in the modern style. It displays flavors of black cherries and cassis, with vanilla and char from oak, and a sweet herb note. Almost sweet, but fundamentally dry, it's a nice steak wine.

Aromas of toasted oak, coffee and dried black fruit lead the nose. The palate offers sour cherry, espresso, dried sage and ground green pepper but there's not enough fruit richness to stand up to the astringent wood tannins that leave a mouth-drying finish.
A definite improvement on the 2007 version of this wine, it shows some herbaceous character, along with ripe apricot and pear fruits. There's a touch of spice as well, which adds character. Screwcap.
This old-vine wine has considerable youthful acidity and a core of firm tannins. Both those elements suggest a wine that needs to soften through aging. Drink from late 2020.
So pretty and polished, with such an attractive aroma. Light, delicately structured, yet powerful in raspberry and cherry fruit, gingerbread and vanilla. Just a lovely glass of red wine to drink now.
Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Schloss Lieser 2016 Thomas Haag Wehlener Sonnenuhr Spätlese Riesling (Mosel)
desc: Loads of pink grapefruit, lychee and peach are rimmed by a margarita-like edge of salt and lime here. While spry and invigorating, it's a sunnier expression of spätlese than the producer's Niederberg Helden bottling. Bold strikes of smoke and struck flint lend gravitas to the finish. Delicious already but it's likely to improve through 2026 and further.

Condrieu also comes in a rarer, sweet style, and here it is, in a wine that is both opulent and exotic. This cuvée de prestige is sweet, certainly, but it has layers of dry botrytis which give it balance. There's also acidity to give the wine a final lift.

wine_name: Cantina Santa Maddalena 2013 Huck am Bach St. Magdalener Red (Alto Adige)
desc: Aromas of red berry and alpine wildflower waft from the glass. Supple tannins and bright acidity support the crushed red cherry, red currant and white almond flavors. Enjoy soon.

wine_name: Simone 2007 Winemaker's Collection Pinot Noir (Bío Bío Valley)
desc: Earthy and a touch burnt on the nose, with standard berry and black cherry aromas. The palate is mostly fresh and clean, with honest but limited flavors of dried cherry, spice and tea. Not a strained or forced PN, but basic nonetheless.

The Yiddish word zaftig describes this Merlot perfectly. It's fleshy, with a soft, fat mouthfeel framing ultraripe cherry pie filling, milk chocolate, anise and sandalwood flavors that finish jammy-sweet and spicy.
Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Give this wine time in the bottle. At the age of four years, it's still dry and hard in tannins, with a lockdown mouthfeel. Shows a good core of blackberries, cherries and cassis, with a rich oak overlay. The tannins, acids and a firm minerality suggest extended aging. Hold until 2013, at least.

wine_name: Domaine Charles Baur 2013 Brand Grand Cru Riesling (Alsace)
desc: There is the merest hint of chamomile lift on the nose, pulling all the other flavors heavenwards with it. There is apple as well as lemon zest. The palate is wonderfully pure and totally dry. Here and there more herbal inflections show and more mellow hints of baked apple. This is dry, taut and aromatic, but also clean-cut and precise. Lovely now but with definite aging potential. Drink now through 2030.

Light bodied and fresh tasting, this wine has a pale-pink color, delicate watermelon and raspberry flavors and a lively crisp mouthfeel. Its appetizing palate-cleansing aspect will pair well with a wide variety of foods.
Appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US

desc: This was held back for release after the winery's single-vineyard selects, perhaps because the wine remains stubbornly mute. It's lightly high toned, with stiff tannins. It puts an herbal face forward, though with ample aeration a strong core of tart cherry emerges, along with citrus highlights.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: Ripe pear, canned and fresh peach and Amalfi lemon have an edge of Damask rose about them on the nose of this wine. The palate is juicy but light, dry and lemony, carrying peachiness as a memory on the slender body. The finish is dry, lemony and refreshing.
It's very clean and fresh in aroma, cool and clear in flavor and soft in texture. Vaguely pearlike aromas lead to more vivid and interesting canteloupe flavors on the finish.

wine_name: Château Julien 2000 Barrel Aged Merlot (Monterey County)
desc: On the thin side, with earthy, mushroomy flavors joined to riper ones of blackberries. Toasty oak brings sweet tannins and vanilla to the mix.
Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US

desc: This leads with aromas of white and yellow flowers, while the palate offers grapefruit, lemon drop and a hint of ginger. It's simple but well made and very enjoyable.
Appellation: Fiano di Avellino, Southern Italy, Italy

wine_name: Vie Winery 2005 L'Imaginaire Grenache (Santa Barbara County)
desc: Not a whole lot going on in this soft, simple wine. The cherry, raspberry and root beer flavors are ultraripe, with a liqueured quality, and the finish is semisweet.
Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US

desc: A smooth, silky texture supports ripe black cherry, blackberry, cassis, bay leaf, sage, anise, toast and chocolate flavors. Moderate acidity and firm, ripe tannins provide structure. Long on the finish.
Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US

desc: From a region renowned for its dessert wine comes this easy-to-love white. Despite a lightness to the medium body, this wine has plenty of guts, evident in the liquid gooseberry mouth mixed with lime and dusted with chalk. The flavor of the wine carries through to the long finish, while aromas of pure gooseberry dance in the glass. Drink now, and enjoy.

wine_name: Bethany Vineyard 2012 Gracee Estate Produced Pinot Noir (Washington)
desc: There's no mistaking the variety, with aromas of sarsaparilla, underbrush and cherry, though a rubber-tire note provides some distraction. The cherry, strawberry and cranberry flavors show good concentration, though they seem a bit clunky at times.

Vinified and matured in stainless steel, this is a vibrantly fruity blend of Grenache Blanc, Roussanne and Picpoul. Pristine white peach and grapefruit flavors are accented by wisps of lemongrass and crushed slate. Medium-bodied and crisply concentrated, it's a zippy expression of Châteauneuf-du-Pape Blanc that rewards youthful consumption.

Lime and gardenia are dominant on the nose, with ample powdered sugar as well. Runs toward ripe nectarine and cantaloupe on the palate, with a sweet finish of dried mango. Shows pure Moscato flavors with only a hint of sugary artificiality.

wine_name: Mario Schiopetto 2008 Podere dei Blumeri Red (Venezia Giulia)
desc: This blend of Merlot, Refosco and Cabernet Sauvignon offers dense flavors of plum extract, red currant and bell pepper that are layered with oak, vanilla and chocolate. However, it lacks energy, and you'll notice the warmth of alcohol as well as a bitter, wood finish.

As with the winery's Estate Selection Syrah, the blend here includes 5% Grenache. This reserve shows more barrel influence, with a smoky nose around black fruits. Those darker elements continue throughout, adding bitter chocolate, espresso and black tea to the mix. It's a well-balanced and detailed wine, with a touch of earthy stem and tobacco on the finish.
Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US

desc: Clean, proper and balanced, this Merlot doesn't excite, but gets the job done in a nice way. It's dry, tannic and crisp, with flavors of cherries, tobacco, cola and spices.
Appellation: Oak Knoll District, Napa, California, US

desc: Extraordinary stuff. The aromas practically defy description, packed with smoke, tobacco, cigar box and cured meat, all wrapped around a deep, rich core of black cherries. Picks up even more complexity in the mouth, adding vanilla, plums and dates in an expansive, mouthfilling experience, then—wham—the tannins hit home, sending you reeling and wondering when this wine will finally blossom. Great now, great 20 years from now.
Tasting mature and mellow, this medium-bodied wine has a tinge of amber in the color and offers lean red-cherry and cider flavors.
Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US

desc: Toasted coconut accents the honey and tropical fruit aromas of this wine, which is aged in oak (40%) and stainless steel (60%). It's medium to full in body, with a lively, balanced feel that makes it very drinkable and harmonious.

This limited-production wine comes from a pre-phylloxera Tannat vineyard planted in 1871. Its power and intensity are justified by blackberry fruits shot through with acidity, with a surprisingly elegant, fresh aftertaste. Drink this rare wine from 2023.
A solid, sweet, perfumed wine with dry tannins overlying red fruit and herbal flavors. What this wine lacks in power, it makes up for in the intensity of its pure fruit flavors.

wine_name: Rodney Strong 2003 Estate Vineyards Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
desc: Thin in flavor, tart in acids, this wine struggles to find its fruit, which barely breaks into cola and red cherries. It's dry, with sandpapery tannins.
Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US

wine_name: Youngberg Hill Vineyards 2015 Bailey Block Pinot Noir (McMinnville)
desc: Spicy and leesy, this opens with brambly berry fruit and a slightly earthy scent. The first bottle seemed a bit disjointed, the second tighter and cleaner (both were sealed with bare screwcaps). It should benefit from another couple of years in bottle.
There's a funky herbal, slightly green quality to this wine, possessed of plenty acidity, as the variety is known for, yet muted in its typical floral aromatics and bright fruit.
A little sharp and one-dimensional, but it shows ripe flavors of blackberries and black currants, enhanced with toasty oak. At its best now.

From this inland region east of L.A. comes a Merlot that's simple, hot and flat. Previous vintages have been better, but the heat of '04 took its toll. The wine needs greater concentration of its cherries and blackberries.

Subdued aromas suggesting toasted hazelnut, underbrush and a whiff of pressed rose waft out of the glass. The tight, austere palate suggests powdered sage, mocha, unripe cherry and a hint of blood orange alongside rather astringent tannins.

wine_name: Convergence Zone 2011 Bacchus Vineyard Dewpoint Riesling (Columbia Valley (WA))
desc: As fresh as a young white wine can be, this sappy Riesling opens with lovely floral aromas, that lend the palate a bit of Gewürztraminer-like soapiness. It turns spicy and penetrating, with Meyer lemon and other expressions of tart citrus.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: If this Merlot had greater flavor intensity, it would be spectacular. It's a very nice photocopy of a great Merlot, meaning that the berry and spice fruit is soft in focus but pleasurable. A great value—dry and classy in its own way.
Concentrated and thick aromas of black currant are very tangy and cut by damp woody cedar tones. The palate is very tangy and thick with grape seed, blackberry and oaky vanilla flavors.
Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Louis Jadot 2013 Les Pucelles Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)
desc: This beautifully balanced wine shows toast that counterpoints the generous yellow fruits and acidity. It's a ripe wine, touched by honey, spice and peach flavors. The aftertaste, with its total freshness, is crisp, lively, mouthfilling and refreshing. Drink from 2018.

wine_name: Altocedro 2017 La Consulta Select Red (La Consulta)
desc: A deep-purple tint sets the stage for fleshy blackberry, cassis, fig and cinnamon aromas. On the palate, this blend of Malbec, Cabernet Sauvignon, Tempranillo and Syrah is wide and jammy. Beefy berry, cassis and black-plum flavors land on a fleshy finish with just enough tightness and focus. Drink through 2022.

Gritty red-berry aromas announce a Garnacha that's not overly ripe and definitely not heavy or jammy. A lean palate is slightly acidic and tannic, while this tastes of red currant and plum. Hard tannins circle back on a finish with mild heat.

wine_name: Mailly Grand Cru NV Brut Réserve  (Champagne)
desc: A dry, citrus-driven Champagne, very mineral in character, with a taut and racy style. With 75% Pinot Noir in the blend, it has some hints of toast, pink grapefruit and a firm edge of acidity.

wine_name: Vignobles Brumont 2011 Château Bouscassé Brumaire  (Pacherenc du Vic Bilh)
desc: Harvested in November 2011 from botrytized grapes which have benefited from the autumn mists, the wine is a fine combination of intense acidity and superrich honeyed flavors. It is ready to drink, although it will certainly age. The secret of the wine is its richness combined with fine acidity. Drink ideally from 2018.
Appellation: Pacherenc du Vic Bilh, Southwest France, France

desc: A vanilla-tinged apple bouquet makes an immediate impression. Soft and seemingly sweet, accented by oak, this medium-bodied wine shows plenty of pineapple fruit. The finish is dominated by spicy oak. A formula-made wine for the American mass market-lots of oak and lots of fruit.

wine_name: Stillman Brown 2005 La Mort du Roi Hill of Graceland R.I.P. Red (Paso Robles)
desc: The latest vinous tribute to The King, this Syrah-Alicante blend is dark, soft, sweet, high in alcohol at 16.1% and oaky. Not my favorite kind of wine, but it is what it is.
Designation: La Mort du Roi Hill of Graceland R.I.P.
Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Mommessin 2003 Nid D'Abeille Chardonnay (Vin de Pays d'Oc)
desc: Decently made but modest Chardonnay, with melon flavors that turn tart and earthy, veering toward grapefruit on the finish.
Appellation: Vin de Pays d'Oc, Languedoc-Roussillon, France

desc: Leonetti's Merlot is the only wine among their four annual releases to debut a year early. It's a good thing with this wine, which is smooth and packed with rich black-cherry and cassis fruit flavors. Also in the blend are small amounts of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Petit Verdot. The tannins are slightly granular, and soaked with cocoa flavor, giving it a pleasingly dark, toasty edge.
Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Here's a bargain white wine you'll like for its moderate aromas of hay, citrus, and butter, and rich, lush flavors of grass, nut, and grapefruit and tangerine. Soft and engaging, there's a lot to like for a likeable price. Best Buy.
Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Vins d'Orrance 2010 Kama Chenin Blanc (Western Cape)
desc: A full-flavored and ripe selection, with decadent scents of sweet spice, whole vanilla bean and peanut skin that give depth to the ripe pear and melon fruit. There's a tangy lift to the palate, as flavors of white cranberry and lemon zest keep the mouthfeel fresh. A honeyed almond accent unfolds on the close.

wine_name: Santos & Seixo 2017 Santos da Casa Alvarinho (Vinho Verde)
desc: A crisp, creamy-textured wine that brings together apples, fresh fruitiness and a richer texture. It comes from the northern Vinho Verde region of Monção and Melgaço, whose granite soils are just right for Alvarinho. Drink the wine now.

A bit on the earthy, tobaccoey side, although there are some pretty flavors of blackberries. Tannins are gritty but soft, and girdle the wine in a dense texture. Notable for the long, intense finish, which coats the palate with cassis. May improve with a few years in the cellar.
Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US

wine_name: De Coelo 2009 Terra Neuma Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
desc: An interesting and even a bold wine that will challenge diehard California Pinot lovers. The wine is quite low in alcohol and exceptionally silky and light in the mouth, with an elegant feeling. It's strongly extracted in raspberry fruit, and has lots of sharp, zingy acidity. Doesn't feel knit together at all, but could be a sleeper. Try aging until 2015.
This opens with toasted oak, pressed wild flower and hay aromas. The lean, diluted palate offers butterscotch and tart lemon zest flavors. Although the acidity is brisk, it lacks fruit richness.

wine_name: 3 Horse Ranch Vineyards 2008 Estate Grown Syrah-Mourvèdre
desc: This aromatic wine has notes of raspberry jam, seabreeze, green olive and smoked meat. The flavors are light and lacking in structure and definition.

wine_name: Lamoreaux Landing 2007 Estate Bottled Reserve Chardonnay (Finger Lakes)
desc: The delicate nose on this reserve Chard offers citrus and flowers with a touch of nutty spice. On the palate, it's a straightforward white with elements of lemon citrus, grapefruit and hazelnut. An easy-drinking Chardonnay with class.
Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US

desc: With some age, this is a gloriously ripe and toasty wine. It has a rich character emphasized by the round texture and the creamy mousse. It also has great concentration, bringing together acidity as well as dense secondary flavors. With its rich, mature character, it is best suited for food. It is ready to drink, but will hold well through 2025.

wine_name: Chateau Ste. Michelle 2009 Pinot Gris (Columbia Valley (WA))
desc: With about 6% Viognier in the blend, this tart, dry, racy take on Pinot Gris has unusual complexity. Crisp citrus and pear skin, green apple and lemon verbena roll across the palate. There's a crisp minerality to the acids, and a clean, refreshing finish.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Firm and structured, packed with ripe berry fruits, a touch of pepper and firm, solid tannins. The delicious fruit is sustained by acidity, and a dry, elegant structure.

The second wine of Château Nenin wears its high alcohol easily. It is balanced, showing its dark tannins and juicy Merlot fruitiness in equal measure. It's by no means ready to drink, so age at least until 2018.

Hints of forest and pine needle lend an alpine touch to ripe honey and tangerine flavors in this dry, medium-bodied wine. It's brisk and breezy on the palate, yet nuanced with touches of spice, earth and mineral. Finishes long and steely.

Smoky notes of mocha dominate this wine upon opening. They carry over onto the palate where they coat ripe black-cherry fruit and even leave some of their mocha bitterness. The palate is smooth, full of ripe fruit and rich with all those mocha notes.

Rooty aromas of berry fruits and marzipan lose intensity and turn more grassy as this unfolds. The palate is narrow in scope and breadth but juicy, with oaky plum and spice flavors. The finish is a bit flat in feel but persists with woody spiciness.

Toasty, nutty richness lays itself like a warming blanket over this wine's nose, but underneath some ripe, lemon-edged stonefruit peeps through promisingly. The palate is still dominated by that toasty sheen, but it is only a question of time before the vivid, concentrated fruit integrates this, making the wine more of a unit. It has rich texture, lovely depth, generous fruit and ripe freshness. Drink 2025–2040.

wine_name: Willow Crest 2012 Estate Grown Willow Crest Estate Vineyard Riesling (Yakima Valley)
desc: An uber aromatic wine with notes of flowers, orange peel, jasmine and canned peaches. At 27.2 g/L residual sugar, it drinks medium sweet but overall, the acid keeps it in check.
Designation: Estate Grown Willow Crest Estate Vineyard
Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Aromas of woodland berry, wild herb, violet and camphor mingle together in the glass. Elegantly structured and boasting great intensity, the vibrant palate delivers crushed strawberry, cranberry, orange zest and licorice set against tightly wound but extremely refined tannins. Firm acidity provides the backbone and impeccable balance while a mineral note lends tension. Some may find this almost too ethereal, but others will be dazzled. Drink 2024–2034.

The nose on this Bulgarian Chardonnay might be promising with scents of dill, coconut, fresh apples and herbs. The palate, however, is jagged and disjointed with enamel-eroding acidity combined with flavors of vanilla, leafy stalks and sour green plums. The finish drops suddenly and ends on a smoky, dusty note.

wine_name: Companhia das Quintas 2015 Quinta do Cardo Red (Beira Interior)
desc: From the rugged high landscape in the east of Portugal, this wine has structure, minerality and ripe, juicy red fruits. Its attractive blend of Touriga Nacional, Tinta Roriz and Touriga Franca is now developing well and the wine will be ready from 2019.

Soft in acids and buttery in melted tannins, this wine slides its cherry-berry flavors gently across the palate. It is polished and smooth, with a light but delicious mouthfeel. Turns a bit astringent on the finish as those dusty tannins kick in.

Montenero is a Nero d'Avola, Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot blend that underlines Sicily's winemaking potential. It is ripe with pungent aromas of plum, cherry, wet earth, cigar box and slate; it's soft and velvety in the mouth with dusty tannins. Drink now. Imported by Empson (USA) Ltd.

94—96 Barrel sample. This is the rich wine of the vintage. With its intensen fruit, piles of spice, but excellent balance, this promises flavors of baked apples and intense dried fruits. The botrytis layer is discreet, a hint rather than overpowering.
Fragrant and detailed, this pure Cabernet Franc mixes dried berries and herbs, hints of tar and tobacco, along with well-managed tannins. Everything resolves in a long and lissome finish.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: A light-weight but pretty wine, featuring just enough black-cherry fruit to stand up to some minty overtones. Shows a hint of alcohol on the finish, along with citrusy acidity.

This reflects the intense heat of the vintage, showing mature berry and plum aromas with toasted notes. The palate is warm and shows ripe—nearly over-ripe—black-cherry, chocolate, espresso and spice flavors. It closes with astringent tannins.

Violet, red-berry and dark-spice aromas shape the nose on this young, vibrant red. The savory, easy-drinking palate offers juicy Morello cherry, licorice and a hint of white pepper alongside bright acidity and smooth, supple tannins. It shows the lighter side of Nebbiolo and is ready to enjoy now. Drink through 2024.
A blend of Grenache (52%), Syrah (25%) and Mourvèdre, this aromatic brooder offers notes of cherry, pepper, herbs and coffee. It's full bodied with tight core of cherry flavors that linger.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Bortolomiol 2005 Brut Millesimato Motus Vitae  (Prosecco di Valdobbiadene)
desc: The idea here is to present a more structured and sophisticated Brut with emphasis on the nutty tones and mature peach. The wine succeeds in this regard but the whole point of Prosecco is to be light and fun; this ultimately lacks those sharp, well-defined fruit tones you might expect.

wine_name: Mazzi 2001 Punta di Villa  (Amarone della Valpolicella Classico)
desc: Raw at first, but it comes around. Early sauvage aromas yield to dried fruit, a touch of dill and butter, and char. The palate is all about red fruit, with cherry and tar dominant. Has a bit of a lactic, creamy quality at the end.
Appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy

desc: Judith Beck's namesake wine is rich, opulent, piled high with ripe fruit and sweet, structured tannins. The wine has floral notes, chocolate and great complexity. For aging over 4–5 years.

A flowery, almost violet-like note marks the attractive bouquet. It's light in body—a true easy-drinker—with clarity, balance and style. It's streamlined as opposed to being chunky, with plenty of oak adding licorice and butter qualities to the finish. The black-cherry core guarantees a fruit-filled ride; it's a sure-fire winner, especially at this price point. Best Buy.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: Very rich and flamboyantly fruity, with tropical papaya, mango and pineapple flavors, finished with Asian spices and vanilla. For all the richness, it's totally dry and crisp.
Appellation: Mt. Harlan, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Grgich Hills 2009 Miljenko's Vineyard Estate Grown Petite Sirah (Napa Valley)
desc: Good thing they held this back for more than four years. It's still so tannic, but is beginning to mellow, and should emerge from its cocoon after 2017. The flavors are ripe and complex, suggesting blackberries and cassis liqueur, with a roasted meat and black-pepper savoriness. High alcohol gives it dry heat that will pair nicely with soft cheeses.

wine_name: Chateau Ste. Michelle 2003 Cold Creek Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
desc: This wine retains some of the vineyard's firm, taut black cherry fruit, but its edges seem sanded down, smoothed over. It feels oddly soft in the mouth, but rough in the finish, somehow manipulated. This exceptional vineyard is capable of much more.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: An oak-aged vino joven with a nose of cherry, rubber and raspberry. At first taste, it seems overtly buttery, as if the young oak were sitting atop the wine. As you get into it, that oak seems less obvious and more integrated. Still, it's a touch bland, yet competent.
Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain

wine_name: Xavier Flouret 2009 Nationale 7 Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
desc: Pretty and fresh, with vibrant, well-defined strawberry fruit on the nose set against a backdrop of white flowers. Turns a bit simple and fleeting in the mouth. Drink up.

Complex and meaty, this deeply colored Syrah from a family estate vineyard oozes flavors of toasted oak, pepper, grilled cherries (if there is such a thing) and grilled beef. There is more going on than just fruit and oak, as the earthy-spicy tones meld with fine-grain tannins. This kept getting better hours after opening and should mature well through 2018.
Appellation: Red Hills, Lake County, California, US

wine_name: Château la Gaffelière 2014 Château Chapelle d'Aliénor  (Bordeaux Supérieur)
desc: Produced by the winemaking team from Château la Gaffelière in Saint-Emilion, this is a fine, smooth and ripe wine. It has black fruits and a structure that is well integrated into the rich wood and acidity. Drink this fine wine from 2018.

Lovely aromas of perfumed berry, rose petal, aromatic herb and baking spice set the tone on this fragrant red. The ethereally elegant, medium-bodied palate is all about finesse and balance, delivering succulent red cherry, juicy raspberry, cinnamon and a dash of white pepper. It's nicely balanced, with polished tannins and fresh acidity. It's already accessible but will also age well over the next several years or more. Drink through 2026.

wine_name: Meeker 2015 Scharf Family Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Dry Creek Valley)
desc: An herbal, earthy nose leads to high-toned flavors of cassis and red currant in this red wine, which becomes full bodied and thickly concentrated on the midpalate.
Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US

wine_name: Kirkland Signature 2011 Cuvée de Nalys Red (Châteauneuf-du-Pape)
desc: A $20 Châteauneuf-du-Pape? Yup, and it's pretty darn good, too. Thyme and clove notes accent the black cherry fruit, and meaty, savory flavors emerge on the palate. It's  appropriately full bodied and perhaps a bit rustic, but satisfying. Drink now and over the next few years.

wine_name: Albert Bichot 2018 Domaine Long-Depaquit Montée de Tonnerre Premier Cru  (Chablis)
desc: Lifted and ethereal notes of dried and fresh lemon peel dominate this wine's open nose. On the palate, the focus shifts to a cool, intense, chalky core around which freshness and juiciness are bundled. This is concentrated and bright, carrying a cool, stony undertone. Drink 2025–2040.
Designation: Domaine Long-Depaquit Montée de Tonnerre Premier Cru

desc: From Robert Hill Smith's (Yalumba) western outpost, this is a medium-bodied, crisp Cabernet with leafy, tea-like notes, decent cassis fruit and a touch of chocolate. Finishes tart and slightly dusty, but probably not for long cellaring; drink now-2015.
A great value wine, Cusumano's cheerful Syrah is aged in stainless steel to lock in its fresh berry nuances. The wine's texture is clean and simple, but nicely smooth and soft as well.
This is ripely tropical, with mango and spice notes that are edged with a more yeasty character, giving an unbalanced quality to this otherwise opulent wine.

Foxy berry and milk chocolate aromas lead to a muscular palate that's a bit soupy and thick. Heavy oak and related chocolaty flavors leave little room for expression of fruit, while this turns toward green on a warm finish.
Delicately scented, this opens with aromas of white flower and a whiff of orchard fruit. The fresh palate offers lemon and pear alongside bright acidity and a tangy hint of crushed oyster shell.

Full-bodied and intense, this delicious wine opens with aromas of woodland berry, star anise, chopped herbs, underbrush and a whiff of light oak. The firm palate doles out ripe black cherry, licorice, sage and chopped mint alongside big, velvety tannins and fresh acidity.

A fuller, more California style of Pinot with reduced black cherry and cough drop aromas followed by a medium-round palate with sweet cherry, chocolate and herbal flavors. It's hefty but not fat or flabby, with cola and medicinal aftertastes.
Whiffs of yellow wildflowers and white stone fruit form the subtle nose. The lean palate offers mere suggestions of pear and Meyer lemon alongside racy acidity.

wine_name: Chakana 2004 Estate Selection Red (Luján de Cuyo)
desc: Heavily toasted and loaded with black cherry and blackberry aromas, this blend of Cabernet, Malbec and Petit Verdot pushes cola, chewy plum and black-fruit flavors. The back end is all about coffee, mocha and bitter chocolate, and as a whole this wine shows Argentina in a fine light. As for the winery, Chakana almost always gets it right.
Appellation: Luján de Cuyo, Mendoza Province, Argentina

wine_name: Venica & Venica 2015 Ronco del Cerò Sauvignon (Collio)
desc: This opens with subtle aromas suggesting white flower, hay and dried aromatic herb. The medium-bodied palate offers juicy yellow peach and a hint of grapefruit while a salty hint of mineral marks the close.

wine_name: Covenant 2016 Solomon Lot 70 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
desc: This wine is sourced from vineyards in Mount Veeder and Oakville planted by the late Leslie Rudd. Tannic, it is layered in black licorice, black pepper and high-toned red fruit. Structured and powerfully full bodied, it retains underlying freshness that keeps it balanced and complex.

A blend of Negroamaro and 15% Malvasia Nera, this opens with aromas of dark berry and toast. The palate offers ripe blackberry, black cherry, mocha and allspice alongside firm tannins. It ends on a note of bitter almond.

From the celebrated Bussia cru, this elegant Nebbiolo opens with aromas of candied fruit, cherry liqueur, licorice and soft spice. There's a touch of white mineral and chopped mint or garden herb at the back and the wine ends with a long, velvety feel.

wine_name: Terre Rouge 2006 Sentinel Oak Vineyard Pyramid Block Syrah (Shenandoah Valley (CA))
desc: Here's a big, juicy, imposingly rich Syrah that's so stuffed with primary fruit character, it needs time in the cellar to come around. Tasted in January, it's enormous in sweet, jammy blackberries, melted milk chocolate, licorice, cherry pie filling and all kinds of peppery spices. Better sometime in 2010, and could become quite dramatic after that.
Appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US

wine_name: Edna Valley Vineyard 2012 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
desc: Hearty aromas of plum and dried black cherries are bolstered by warm cedar tones, a touch of tar, crushed peppercorns and chopped garden herbs. The palate is complex, with lots of acidity and peppery spice, showing flavors of oregano and marjoram on a base of plum fruit. It's dense with flavors but medium in body, and very lively.
Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Dark-black-plum aromas are fresh but dense on the nose of this bottling, which also offers tarragon, tobacco and bay leaf scents. The eucalyptus streak is strong on the tip of the sip but then warms up into baked blackberry and black-cherry flavors.
Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Materra Cunat Family Vineyards 2010 Cunat Reserve Estate Grown Red (Oak Knoll District)
desc: This is a tightly wound wine, brimming with acids, tannins and oak that give structure to exceptionally rich, ripe fruit. The black currants and cherries have complex edges of minerals and anise, leading to a long, spicy finish. Don't even think of opening the bottle before 2017.
Appellation: Oak Knoll District, Napa, California, US

wine_name: Red Stitch 2017 Sierra Mar Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
desc: The complex nose of this bottling shows pomegranate, rose petals, strawberry and bay leaf aromas. The palate is very grippy and show deft restraint from a vineyard that can be quite ripe, offering nuanced flavors of hibiscus, pomegranate and anise.
Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Aromas and flavors of rhubarb and pomegranate dominate in this well-made, simply structured wine. It is softly layered in oak and balanced by bright acidity and juicy ripeness.

wine_name: Pazo de Barrantes 2006 Pazo Barrantes Albariño (Rías Baixas)
desc: Almond, sherry and banana aromas start it out. The palate is mellow and smooth, with apple and touches of lemon. There's ring and some zing on the finish, but not too much as the wine is beginning to show signs of reaching early maturity. Drink immediately.

wine_name: Steele 2016 Catfish Vineyard Centennial Vines Zinfandel (Lake County)
desc: This excellent wine is bold in flavor and big in structure. It offers intense blackberry and black-cherry flavors framed by firm tannins and a full body. Light accents of chaparral, vanilla and cedar add extra interest and complexity.
Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US

desc: Earthy aromas of scorched earth, mocha and green bell pepper come together on this Cabernet Sauvignon. The dense, rather evolved palate offers prune, clove and toasted almond alongside close-grained tannins.

Violet and floral boysenberry aromas show earthiness and leather after airing. This feels supple and deep, with just enough acidic lift. Toasty, blackened cassis and blueberry flavors show a hint of bacon, while toast, spice and chocolate flavors grace a solid finish. Drink through 2024.

wine_name: Viña Santa Cruz 2006 Chamán Gran Reserva Cabernet Sauvignon (Colchagua Valley)
desc: Here's yet another very nice, ready-to-drink Cabernet from Chile. Tight and complete on the nose, with aromas of cassis, cherry and tar. The palate is packed deep with sweet cassis fruit, which is accented by tobacco and burnt sugar. Shows some unabsorbed oak and chocolate on the finish, but generally speaking it's in fine shape.

wine_name: Spring Valley Vineyard 2005 Uriah Red Wine Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
desc: Purple and black fruits spread across the midpalate, with herbal, tannic flavors from the Franc and floral highlights from the PV. There is a bit of a hole in the middle, and the tannins seem to hit a bit hard following that drop-off. It could be a phase, or it could be a failing.
Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: La Fenêtre 2008 À Côté Chardonnay (Santa Barbara County)
desc: Shows the ripe pineapple fruit, acidity, minerality and above all sweet, smoky oak that mark a rich California Chardonnay. But there's something off. Hard to say exactly what, but it's in the taste. Like a smattering of mold or shriveled grapes that's off-putting.
Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US

desc: There's a tiny touch of raw apple or apple skin that gives this Barbaresco a bright, vertical, aromatic lift. That tiny volatility doesn't distract from the overall picture and base aromas of spice, cola and red fruit still manage to shine through just fine.

A high note of pure, tart red cherry on the nose sets a tone of freshness and brightness. The palate adds lightness and creates a triple virtue of translucent, red-fruited charm. This is a very playful wine with a gorgeous emphasis on silkiness. A lovely whiff of white pepper adds a tingling note to the juicy red cherry on the finish. Lovely and elegant.

wine_name: Cellier des Princes 2016 La Chasse des Princes Red (Châteauneuf-du-Pape)
desc: Made from 90% Grenache, this decadent wine heaves with luscious black-cherry and violet-candy flavors. It's full bodied and plush but pristine in fruit quality. Very fine, persistent tannins and piquant spice extend the finish. Delicious already the wine should reach peak through 2026.

wine_name: David Hill 2007 Barrel Select Estate Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
desc: Wild berries, cranberries and pungent herbaceousness characterize this Barrel Select Pinot Noir. It seems a little light at first, then gathers itself in a focused, spicy midpalate that nicely integrates the fruit and herbs.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: This deeply structured and layered Barbaresco delivers thick aromas of bitter chocolate, mature cherry, cola and leather. It's a young wine, with tight astringency and firm tannins, that needs to age another five years in the bottle before the wine is ready to drink.

wine_name: Quinta do Casal Branco 2014 Lobo e Falcão Reserva Red (Tejo)
desc: This is a wood-aged blend of Alicante Bouschet, Syrah and Touriga Nacional, producing a wine that is both structured and ripe with black fruits. It has considerable acidity, spice along with some aging potential. Drink from 2018.

wine_name: Torres de Anguix 2004 A  (Ribera del Duero)
desc: Jumpy and young, with a touch of pickle on the nose. In the mouth, it's all about high-toned red fruit, particularly cherry and raspberry. Very bright and a bit acidic, but with that comes a certain freshness that keeps the wine alert. Should get better with some bottle age. Imported by Hand Picked Selections.
Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain

desc: This wine celebrates the 19 generations (mostly called Alphonse) that have run this top Sancerre estate since the 17th century. The wine offers ripe fruit, bold quince and spice flavors, with hints of apricot. Structured and concentrated, it is a wine to savor, but not before 2019.

wine_name: Château Lamothe de Haux 2016 Traditionnelle  (Cadillac Côtes de Bordeaux)
desc: Juicy with attractive black-currant flavors, this Chobart family wine is rich with tannins and fruitiness. Still firm and darkly textured, it needs time. Drink from 2022.
Appellation: Cadillac Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France

desc: Ripe, rich and full-bodied, this is a smooth, opulent wine. It has weight and tannins which give structure to the full fruit and delicious acidity. This is a wine to savor with its red berries, juicy flavor and generous aftertaste. Drink from 2017.

wine_name: Ducleaux 2018 Pink Slip Rosé (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
desc: This rosé of Grenache, Syrah and Mourvèdre is a very pretty pale-peach color. Aromas of cut apple, biscuit and gummy are followed by lightly styled, center-focused flavors. It pulls up on the finish.
Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Jean-Marc Bernhard 2015 Wineck-Schlossberg Grand Cru Riesling (Alsace)
desc: Enticingly bracing grapefruit freshness streams from the glass. The palate has a milder sort of freshness—think very ripe bright lemon notes. The flavors are pleasingly focused—sharp and clean, with dryness and a soaring freshness that lightens up everything. There is a wonderfully light touch here. It's a beautiful and totally refreshing wine. Drink 2017–2030.

wine_name: Zepaltas 2012 Devoto Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
desc: This remains a vineyard site to watch, a spot within the Sebastopol Hills section now widely being called West Sonoma Coast. The area is also known for heirloom apples, much of which go into artisanal cider. Weighty and inconceivably bright, the Pinot is layered in fresh cranberry and earthy pomegranate, dusted in baking spice and structured in firm tannins. About half of the wine went through whole-cluster fermentation.

wine_name: Wilson 2007 Dorothy's Vineyard Syrah (Dry Creek Valley)
desc: Frankly as sweet as Port, with sugary blackberry jam and chocolate-covered raisin flavors and high, brandied alcohol. Not bad for a dessert wine, but inappropriate for a table wine.
Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US

wine_name: Pech Merle 2015 T-Bar-T Ranch Cabernet Franc (Alexander Valley)
desc: Aromatically shy, in contrast to its showy tannins, this wine is huge in structure and weight, with a jammy core of black cherry and raspberry dusted in clove.

Familia Schroeder is making good, restrained wines in Neuquén. This Merlot won't rock your world but it will deliver firm, fresh raspberry flavors, food-friendly acidity and solid tannins. And it's even got some chewy sweetness.

wine_name: Domaine Coteau 2002 Reserve Pinot Noir (Yamhill County)
desc: The cola scents characteristic of Oregon Pinot dominate the nose, leading into firm, plummy fruit with interesting layers of black raspberry and black cherry. Turns thin and tannic.
Appellation: Yamhill County, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: Reductive and sulfurous, this wine tastes of big oak, baked pineapple and hazelnut.
This wine, which includes a small amount of Gewürztraminer, is off dry, with powdered sugar, lime, Meyer lemon and orange creamsickle flavors.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

wine_name: Il Falchetto 2007 Bricco Paradiso  (Barbera d'Asti Superiore)
desc: Here's a mature expression of Barbera with ripe notes of blackberry, plum and dark fruit. The wine is dense and thickly extracted with a soft velvety texture and loads of oak influence. It will, no doubt, evolve into a beautiful wine in two or three more years: All the right elements are there and the wine seems poised for harmony and balance.

wine_name: Aljibes 2012 Viña Aljibes Cabernet  Sauvignon-Syrah-Cabernet Franc-Tempranillo Red (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
desc: Plum and berry aromas are lively and come with a mild scent of animal fur. This blend of four grapes, led by Tempranillo, feels blocky and loosely defined, while flavors of plum, raspberry and a touch of herbal green finish spicy and woody. Will function best as an everyday wine.
Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain

desc: Bright and earthy, this informal red offers aromas of dark-skinned berry, leafy underbrush, tilled soil and a whiff of clove that carry over to the easy-drinking palate. Racy acidity and mild, fleeting tannins provide the easygoing framework.

There's a pretty smoky element to this wine that comes off as cured beef or bresaola backed by graphite and ground slate. From the faraway 2001 vintage, the wine boasts elegant tertiary aromas of cola, black licorice and candied fruit with some sweetness on the close. Drink now.
Appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
