Delicate aromas recall white spring flower and green apple. The bright palate offers mature Bartlett pear, nectarine and a hint of bitter almond alongside brisk acidity.

White stone-fruit and yellow spring-flower aromas align with a whiff of bread crust on this elegantly sparkling wine. Bright and linear, the tangy palate offers mature yellow apple, lemon drop and hazelnut.

Pressed iris, red-skinned berry, underbrush and a whiff of rosemary lead the nose on this 100% Sangiovese. The supple, juicy palate delivers black cherry, white pepper, leather and star anise alongside velvety, polished tannins. It's already accessible but will also age well for the next several years or more. Drink through 2025.

Considerably less ripe than the winery's Sonoma Valley bottling, with tomato, beet, sauteed mushroom and herb aromas and flavors, although there's a chewy core of black cherry in there. Of course, Carneros is a cold, foggy place. I don't think this wine will age, but this is a solidly made, good wine. It's a question of pairing it with appropriate food. —S.H.
A blend of black-cherry, chocolate and herb flavors. Moderate body and powdery tannins round it off for a pleasant quaff.

Tart-sweet cherry-berry fruit shines through the earthy notes here. The typical metallic quality is present but restrained. This light to medium-weight wine is tasty, focused basic Pinotage. A nice casual choice for grilled meats.

wine_name: Vicente Gandia 2016 Finca del Mar Monastrell-Petit Verdot (Valencia)
desc: Plum and berry aromas are full but restrained. On the palate, this blend of Monastrell and Petit Verdot is fleshy and pulpy. Oaky plum and cassis flavors fade away slowly on the finish before getting replaced by more overt oak notes.

This Bordeaux-style blend includes 44% Merlot, 32% Cabernet Franc and 24% Malbec. The fruit flavors are light and lean toward red berry notes, while the mouthfeel is dominated by thick, drying tannins. It finishes short and chalky.
Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US

wine_name: Telmo Rodríguez 2008 Altos Lanzaga Gran Viñedo  (Rioja)
desc: From a mediocre vintage, it seems as though the winery poured on the fully toasted oak to cover up marginal fruit. This smells like burnt meat and rubber, tastes charred and baked, and finishes blackened and overly toasty, with a choppy feel and hard tannins.

wine_name: Henri Bourgeois 2017 La Côte des Monts Damnés  (Sancerre)
desc: This steep slope of vines dominates the village of Chavignol, home to the Bourgeois family. An aromatic wine, it is crisp, textured and full of citrus and gooseberry flavors. This beautiful wine is still young, so wait to drink until 2019.
Toasty, nutty and even eggy, there's apple and caramel on the palate, though the midpalate feels a little hollow. Sours up on the finish, with herb and anise.

wine_name: Peterson 1997 Bradford Mountain Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
desc: Firm, ripe and fruity, with a nice mix of plums, berries and earth. The mountain fruit shows good acids, some mineral elements, and a long, complex finish with a fair amount of earth and barnyard. A distinctive, earthy style.
Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US

desc: In the 19th century, this was part of the large Figeac properties. Today owned by the Leydet family, the vineyard has produced a balanced, richly structured wine, with fine tannins and juicy black fruits. Its weight is balanced by acidity and freshness that comes through at the end. Drink from 2023.

wine_name: Stag's Leap Wine Cellars 2014 S.L.V. Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
desc: Estate-grown, this wine is juicy and expansive, with an approachability that makes it instantly pleasing on the palate. Black currant, graphite and dark-chocolate flavors meet brushy dried herb and toasted oak, integrating into a lengthy finish.

wine_name: SERVE 2018 Chevalier de Dyonis Pinot Noir (Romania)
desc: Ruby red in the glass, this wine has aromas of red raspberry, ripe cherry and baking spices. In the mouth it is pleasantly tart, with flavors of cassis and black cherry.

wine_name: Gallo of Sonoma 1995 Sonoma County Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
desc: Rich and concentrated, with black olives and blackberry fruit; the mouthfeel is ripe and lush, leading to a long, layered finish. A very good wine made even more attractive by the price. Best Buy.

wine_name: Cosecheros y Criadores 2011 Sweet Torito Moscato (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
desc: This corny looking bottle of sweet wine is not bad, and in some ways it is pretty good. Tropical fruit and gardenia aromas are clean, and the palate is friendly in feel, with likable banana and melon flavors. As stated, this is perfectly good for a simple sweet white.
Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain

wine_name: Terre de la Custodia 2011  Montefalco Rosso
desc: Aromas of leafy underbrush, tilled soil, game, and ripe black fruit lead the nose on this savory red. On the palate, notes of grilled sage and mocha back up the juicy black cherry and crushed raspberry fruit. Give it until 2016–2017 for assertive tannins to unwind.

wine_name: Château de Nages 2017 Buti Nages Red (Costières de Nîmes)
desc: Intensely ripe black-cherry and berry flavors are highlighted by notes of violet and crushed stone in this easy-drinking but elegant wine. It's a plush, intensely fruity wine fringed by fine, supple tannins. Fresh mineral tones and a lift of acidity brighten the finish.
Appellation: Costières de Nîmes, Rhône Valley, France

desc: This juicy all-Merlot bottling boasts blackberry and green peppercorn aromas. The firm palate doles out black currant, tobacco, clove and licorice flavors, framed by crunchy tannins. Enjoy through 2020.

A low-priced everyday Chard of sophistication and elegance. It's dry and wonderfully crisp, with subtlely oaked flavors of pineapples, peaches, green apples, pears and kiwis. Easy to find, with more than 12,000 cases produced.
This opens with ripe aromas of candied fruit and sweet prune. There's a touch of crisp cherry cola, with a general tartness on the finish.

wine_name: Bodegas Herederos Ribas 1998 Ribas de Cabrera Red (Vi de Taula de Balears)
desc: The Balearic Islands seem to have what it takes when it comes to fine reds, especially when importer supreme Jorge Ordonez is the one ferreting them out. This three-grape blend is fascinating and flavorful; it has a floral nose, gorgeous plum, berry, vanilla and cinnamon flavors, and a smooth, chocolaty finish. The wine is round, complete and unusual; it's a real find.
Appellation: Vi de Taula de Balears, Spanish Islands, Spain

wine_name: Vista Hills 2008 Skyraider Reserve Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)
desc: Clean, crisply defined fruit tastes like ripe strawberries, with side notes of melon and orange peel. Good acidity, and the winemaker has let the fruit steal the show—if there are new barrels involved, they are certainly in the background. Medium-bodied, nicely balanced and built for cellaring over the next 6–8 years.
Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: This nose is rich, savory in aromas of blackberry, black olive, chocolate and iron. A flush, pulpy palate is tannic and overall a bit broad and clunky, while friendly black plum and cassis flavors darken up on a thick finish. Big fruit and a ripe flavor profile are what this Mencía delivers.

wine_name: Quinta de Chocapalha 2013 Reserva Branco White (Lisboa)
desc: This blend encourages the richness of the Chardonnay and the crispness of the Arinto. Wood-aging smoothes things out and brings a touch of ginger as well as toast. The wine is full on the mouth and still young. Drink from 2017.

Erath's Leland Pinot Noir is among the lightest of the 2007 designates, a clear and pale wine with an elegance that is almost rosé-like. Soft scents of crushed roses and hints of mocha lead into a mouthful of nougat wafer and almond paste flavors, wrapped around sweet cherry fruit.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

wine_name: Henri Goutorbe NV Cuvée Prestige Premier Cru  (Champagne)
desc: A wine with some rich maturity in its aromas, which goes right through the rounded, ripe palate. It has some power from the Pinot Noir element in its blend, with white fruit flavors and intensity. A mature wine, rich and satisfying, that's good with food.

wine_name: Napa Cellars 2013 Classic Collection Pinot Noir (Napa Valley)
desc: A generic expression of the variety with some notions of ripe plum, dark cherry and black pepper, this straightforward wine is ready to drink now. It takes on full tannic strength on the finish.

wine_name: Arnaud Baillot 2015 Sous Frétilles Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)
desc: The white wines of Pernand-Vergelesses have managed to preserve a cool, crisp character even in warm 2015. This wine has the citrus well to the fore along with flavors of wood aging and spice. It is tangy and mineral, with a bright textured aftertaste. Drink from 2020.

Made entirely with Merlot, this has a shy nose that eventually reveals subtle aromas of black-skinned fruit, grilled herb and caramel. The round, accessible palate provides black cherry, vanilla and a hint of baking spice, all framed by smooth tannins. Enjoy soon.

Invigorating pineapple and crisp white-grapefruit flavors are jolted by high-toned electric acidity in this sprightly off-dry wine. It's an easy-drinking juicy sip but nuanced subtly by hints of crushed slate and salt. This is ready to drink now.

wine_name: Kendall-Jackson 2002 Grand Reserve Sonoma-Mendocino-Napa Counties Merlot (California)
desc: This wine is ultrasoft in both acidity and tannins. The flavors are complex, ranging from cherries and tobacco to sweet herbs and oak. But it loses points because it's too soft and could use greater structure.

wine_name: Georg Frischengruber 2018 Ried Steiger Federspiel Grüner Veltliner (Wachau)
desc: Green pear freshness dominates the nose. The palate comes across as juicy, bright and textured, alive with pear, yeast and lemon. This is totally fruity, appetizing and moreish.

wine_name: Bravium 2018 Wiley Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
desc: This attractive and well-balanced wine is relatively light in color but generous in flavors, offering bright red- and black-cherry notes accented lightly by oak spices. A peppery, smoky mushroom streak builds on the palate and finish, adding tempting complexity.
Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US

desc: An interesting wine. It comes from a southerly part of Napa Valley many consider too cool for fine Cab. But this was a warm vintage. The result is very ripe fruit, wrapped in robust, hard tannins that make the wine too young to drink now. The blackberry, currant, cherry and new oak flavors are delicious, but this Cab needs at least through 2008 to come into its own, and will be better after 2010.

wine_name: Hermann J. Wiemer 2015 Cabernet Franc (Seneca Lake)
desc: Hermann J. Wiemer's standard-label Cabernet Franc suggests a freshly fruity yet delicate expression of red wine. Brisk black-cherry and berry flavors are sheer and perfumed, flecked by touches of graphite and violet. It's delightfully light bodied, framed in soft feathery tannins and a silky mineral-rich finish.
Appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US

desc: An interesting wine that's dry, yet shows some distinctly sweet notes. The apple-grape front end is fruity, somewhat Riesling-like. The appealing, tart green apple close turns crisper and drier. Light weight with good acidity, a good choice for moderately spicy foods, and pretty tasty on its own.
Blue fruit, herbs and brown spices vie for attention. The palate brings lighter-styled yet still generous-feeling fruit flavors that linger.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Fresh and linear, this opens with fragrant purple flower, red berry and new leather scents. The firm, youthfully austere palate is loaded with finesse, offering crunchy red cherry, fresh strawberry and licorice notes with taut, fine-grained tannins and vibrant acidity. Give it time to unwind and fully develop. Drink 2019–2028.
Appellation: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy

desc: An organic blend of 80% Grechetto and 20% Trebbiano, this shows big structure and density. It almost feels like a red wine in the mouth because of the creamy texture and weight. The bouquet is fragrant and intense with citrus, honey and apricot aromas.

A roasted, rubbery nose deals a proprietary mix of savory blueberry, tea and grassy hints. In the mouth, this red blend is raw and pulls inward. Minty, herbal berry flavors are green at heart, while any fruit this has is short-lived on an herbal finish.

wine_name: Greenwood Ridge 2013 Estate Bottled Pinot Noir (Mendocino Ridge)
desc: This has a rather deep red color and a slightly smoky rim. It offers profuse aromas of black cherry and blackberry, medium to full body and a generous texture. It's enjoyable for the fruit flavor, and easy to drink due to the soft texture. The finish is lingering and almost sweet.
Appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US

wine_name: R. Lopez de Heredia 1996 Viña Tondonia Reserva  (Rioja)
desc: Not old by Tondonia standards, in fact it's a new release. Yet it's already orange and rusty in color, with aromas of citrus peel, crushed spice and subdued berry. The palate is lean, with sharp acidity (the key to this wine's longevity). Lots of pulse and zip on the finish. Spent five years in barrel.

wine_name: Château de Berne 2015 Ludovic de Beauséjour Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
desc: This wine has a rich background to support its perfumed red fruits. Raspberry and mandarin-orange flavors roll around the mouth easily, with only the lightest sense of structure. It is an immediately attractive, balanced wine.

wine_name: Vignerons de Caractère 2004 Marquis de Fontséguille Red (Vacqueyras)
desc: Interesting but a bit disjointed, with dark coffee and date notes, but also bright berries. Finishes with soft tannins but also crisp acidity.

Robust, deep and candied on the nose, with rooty richness, medicinal notes and complexity. The palate is smooth, meaty, healthy and suave, with lush black fruit, prune and earthy flavors. Long, likable and showing a lot of depth and structure. Drink now through 2014.

Inviting aromas of baked plum, exotic spice, blue flower and a balsamic whiff of menthol all take shape in the glass. It's full bodied but accessible, delivering spiced prune, fruitcake, mocha and star anise. Polished tannins provide finesse. Drink through 2023.

Both pear and citrus pith inform the shy nose of this wine. The palate expresses more of that pithy citrus, adding streaks of bright lemon and the slightest touch of salty yeast. It's concentrated yet taut and utterly refreshing, with an almost cleansing quality.

wine_name: Red Tail Ridge 2012 Obscure Red Varietal Series RTR Estate Vineyard Teroldego (Finger Lakes)
desc: Smoke and granite lend earthiness to luscious black cherry and plum flavors in this bold, powerfully constructed Teroldego. Framed with tannins and a dusting of licorice and spice, it's a highly promising wine made from an unusual Italian grape variety.
Designation: Obscure Red Varietal Series RTR Estate Vineyard
Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US

desc: A subtle hint of creamy lemon appears on the nose. The palate comes in with more lemon freshness that is bright, intense and very refreshing. The body is slender and dry.

wine_name: Mount Eden Vineyards 2013 Estate Bottled Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Cruz Mountains)
desc: There's an unparalleled woody intensity on the nose of this offering, with cigar box, myrrh, incense and bay leaf decorating the black peppercorn, herb-laced salt, dark chocolate and black plum aromas. The palate's leathery flavors are woven into fine-grained tannins, revealing flashes of elderberry, violet and gravel. Drink 2019–2033.
Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Veramonte's first high-end Ritual Sauvignon is a big success. The nose is mellow, refined and minerally as opposed to pungent and feline. The feel is fresh, clean as a razor, and easygoing, with lime, nectarine and passion fruit flavors. Long and lightly green on the classy finish.

From an always-impressive estate, this vintage is superb, offering big tannins plus but also generous black fruits and powerful ripeness. Dense and with a good structure for aging, the wine will develop slowly and will not be ready before 2026.

wine_name: Castello di Farnetella 2002  Chianti Colli Senesi
desc: Fresh and pure, if a tad light in weight and concentration. Fine plum and berry aromas and flavors convey ripeness, which is confirmed on the smooth, medium-bodied palate. Should go well with milder foods, things like roast pork loin or poultry. Supple and well made.

A very interesting blend composed of 50% Sangiovese, 22% Pinot Noir, 13% Nebbiolo, 7% Mourvèdre, 6% Barbera and 2% Shiraz. Nuances of leather and sweet spice mingle seamlessly with red cherry and fruit cake characteristics; the silky texture and soft tannins carry the earthy notes through the close.

wine_name: Kontos 2016 Dorsey Baker Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
desc: This is an interesting blend of 34% Merlot, 25% Cabernet Sauvignon, 25% Malbec and 19% Petit Verdot. Aromas of vanilla, blackberry, sweet baking spices and anise show themselves, with the barrel influence primary. Ripe, opulent fruit and barrel flavors follow. It's full throttle wine, made in a hedonistic style, with the acidity of the vintage keeping it in check.
Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Juicy fruit is present in this wine, with firm, extracted tannins. It needs time to show its potential black-currant and berry notes. Give it 3–4 years.

Made from 85% Sangiovese, 10% Malvasia and 5% Alicante, it features aromas of blue flower, ripe black fruit and espresso notes. The palate offers black cherry, black pepper, toasted oak and roasted coffee beans. It ends on a bitter, tannic note that dries out the mouth.

A beautiful Pinotage with superb expression and balance. Intriguing aromas of spicy cured meat, pepper, raw vanilla bean and mulled boysenberry abound, while the lush mouth offers concentrated dark fruit flavors of plum preserves and berry pie filling. Enjoyable now thanks to a creamy texture and silk tannins, though this wine also shows the potential to cellar for another 3–5 years.

wine_name: Monte Volpe 2009 Primo Rosso Red (Mendocino County)
desc: Teased in blackberry jam with a sizable structure and robust tannins, the wine combines 42% Petite Sirah with smaller amounts of Syrah, Pinotage, Primitivo, Zinfandel and other varieties into a straightforward package.
Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US

wine_name: Domaine des Baumard 2009 Carte d'Or Chenin Blanc (Coteaux du Layon)
desc: A wine that contrasts extreme sweetness with freshness. It has beautiful acidity as well as a great swathe of sweet peach and orange laced with honeyed cream.
Appellation: Coteaux du Layon, Loire Valley, France

wine_name: Lone Birch 2018 Estate Grown Syrah (Yakima Valley)
desc: Showing some reduction initially, the aromas suggest notes of char, black raspberry and gravel. The palate is deft and up front, trailing a bit toward the finish but overall showing good balance. There's plenty of value to be had.
Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: A very crisp Riesling, all green citrus fruits. It has a core backbone of acidity and stoniness, while also allowing more fruity character to shine. For drinking now.

A solid effort from Barbaresco's local cooperative, which should augur well for its single-vineyard riservas that will be released later this year. The normale is a fairly priced, somewhat herbal and tannic wine that shows enough cherry fruit and minty complexity to anchor it in the Very Good range. Astringent on the finish, so give it some time in the cellar or drink with rare beef. Imported by Vias Imports.

93–95. Barrel Sample. Firmly tannic, but also rich in ripe black-fruit tones, this is going to be a fine wine as it develops. The pure berry flavors shine through the structure and acidity. Drink from 2024.

wine_name: West Cape Howe 2007 Book Ends Cabernet Sauvignon (Western Australia)
desc: This wine shows some of the cool-climate notes associated with Western Australia and its maritime climate; green tobacco and other herbs intertwine with bright cassis fruit. At the same time, the fine quality of the tannins is evident in this wine's velvety texture, which makes it a pleasure to drink. Best now–2017.

wine_name: Jim Barry 2012 The Lodge Hill Dry Riesling (Clare Valley)
desc: The Lodge Hill Dry is a solid performer year-in and year-out. This vintage shows a hint of fuel oil alongside green apple, bergamot and clover notes. It's a fine, medium-bodied dry Riesling that broadens out just a little on the long finish.

wine_name: McIntyre Vineyards 2014 Block 3 Estate Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
desc: Very few wines present such intense florality as does this bottling that smells like a potpourri sachet, full of dried violets, dried lavender and eucalyptus, with touches of dust, chipped slate and black plum. Those flowers carry to the palate as well, where lavender, blossoming thyme and green peppercorns show.
Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Dutton-Goldfield 2006 Dutton Ranch Sanchietti Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
desc: This bottling is very vintage-driven, and seems to prefer a warmer year, which 2006 wasn't. It's a delicate, silky and beguiling Pinot Noir, with complex flavors of cherry pie, mocha, rhubarb and pomegranates. But it's a little light. Drink now.
Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US

wine_name: Barnett 2007 Viento Valle Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
desc: With a smooth, silky texture, this Pinot has a certain appeal. The basic flavors are of ripe mashed cherries, Dr. Pepper, chocolate, anise and black pepper. One drawback is the texture, which is sharp, almost acetic. But then, it's a very young wine, and these things can resolve over time. Try sometime in 2010.
Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US

desc: Pours dark and extracted, with rich, ripe chocolate and blackberry preserve flavors. Pretty tannic now, and finishes dry and fruity. Good with chops, steak.
Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US

wine_name: Terroir Al Límit 2015 Terra de Cuques White (Priorat)
desc: Dusty, peachy aromas are mellow, while overall not a lot is happening on the nose. A somewhat collapsed, fallen palate is ultimately a bit flat. Mild apple and spice flavors last on a finish that's slightly bitter and tastes of almond.

Not quite up there with the great '07. More like the ‘06, offering vast, ripe flavors that lack complexity. The pineapple, crème brûlée, apricot, nectarine and honeysuckle flavors taste almost dessert-sweet, accented by caramelized oak.

Made with 85% Merlot, 10% Petit Verdot and the remaining 5% divided between Cabernet Sauvignon and Sangiovese, this opens with delicate aromas of cedar, exotic spice and pine resin. The palate delivers licorice and blueberry jam alongside bracing tannins.

No one says Verdejo is an ager, but this '08 is fading. The nose is soft and peachy, with weight and vanilla. The palate is equally soft and melony, and the green-fruit flavors are starting to turn mealy. Still good enough, but without much spunk it might be better to wait for 2009.

A deep, dark Syrah with cola, spice, pepper, cedar and olive notes to go with more familiar blackberry and mocha. The palate is deep and pure, with juicy acidity pushing herbal berry and layered spice flavors. Has good flow and feel, and overall it strikes the right chords.

A few years of bottle age have mellowed this wine to silky smoothness.  Has the prettiest bouquet of red cherries and smoke, with hints of bacon, thyme, mint and white chocolate.  Equally complex on the palate, with the most generous texture. Pure velvet.

wine_name: Cuvée Lion d'Or 2015 Red (Vin de France)
desc: This blend of 45% Cinsault, 45% Carignan and 10% Syrah offers vanilla-kissed aromas of blackberry, raspberry and plum, as well as a touch of menthol. The slightly creamy, full-flavored palate boasts ripe black-fruit flavors and a touch of milk chocolate, all of which linger through to the medium-length finish.
Appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France

desc: This is a blend of Syrah and Cab Sauvignon. It's very fruity, soft in acidity and slightly sweet, with candied blackberry, cherry and cocoa flavors.
Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Half Cabernet Sauvignon and half Syrah, this sharp and spicy red brings bright berry fruit scents and flavors. A few more years of bottle age will help to smooth it out.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Domaine Bernhard & Reibel 2015 Vieilles Vignes Riesling (Alsace)
desc: Lithe and perfumed notes of mandarin hit the nose before more gentle but refreshing mandarin and tangerine show on the palate of this wine. Pliable and fresh, it has zesty concentration at the core and is a joy to drink.
Shows a lot more fruit that the '77, packing cherry and brown sugar flavors onto a rounder, softer frame. Finishes with hints of tobacco and tea. Fully mature, or maybe a little past peak.

A blend from three of Josef Högl's vineyards, this brings together fruit from the cool west, the center and the warm east of the Wachau. Less focused than other Högl Grüners, it gains from a warmth and roundness, emphasizing sweet melon and pineapple flavors, and a soft finishing acidity and spice.

This plucky red starts with aromas of tobacco, black cherry, spice and olives, followed by spicy black berry fruit, cedar and smoke. Minerals give the wine a crisp character. Pair with roasted meats, stews.

This small producer continues to impress with this floral, impressively made effort, sourced from several vineyards, including Terra de Promissio. Sly layers of raspberry define juicy acidity and sizable tannin and oak that support but don't intrude. The finish continues the theme of vibrancy, lingering in cherry and dried cranberry.

Aromas of yellow stone fruit, spring wildflower and Alpine herb lead the nose. Elegant and linear, the vibrant, savory palate offers yellow peach, apricot and a hint of graphite alongside bright acidity. It closes on an almond note.

wine_name: Wind Rose 2012 Stone Tree Vineyard Primitivo (Wahluke Slope)
desc: Aromatically appealing, this suggests black raspberries, tart cherries and herbs, with light citrus and barrel accents. It's tart and quite restrained for the variety with plumy fruit flavors and a slightly chalky feel to the tannins that may resolve with some additional time in the bottle.
Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: This wine, pure Syrah, shows how well the grape can perform in the granite and schist of the Douro Valley. The wine is spicy, perfumed and structured. Full of black fruits and ripe tannins, it is still aging and will be at its best from 2022.

wine_name: Merry Edwards 2014 Cuvée August Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
desc: Named for Edwards' first grandchild born in this vintage year, this wine is made from fruit sourced from Meredith Estate Vineyard. Velvety smooth and perfumed, it offers piquant pepper and cardamom scents, along with intense rhubarb compote and raspberry flavors. It shows both purpose and quiet power, wrapped in violet and rose.
Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US

desc: The nose on this multigrape blend is gaseous, with forceful berry aromas but little nuance. A tannic, rubbery, rock-hard palate is home to candied black-fruit flavors that are a touch green at the core. Mint and licorice flavors confirm an herbal presence on a brutally tannic finish.

wine_name: Herzog 2014 Variations French Oak Cabernet Sauvignon (North Coast)
desc: Lots of toasted, smoky, coffee-like aromas and flavors coat the raspberry and tart blackberry core of this medium-bodied wine. It's a bit much in terms of oak, but makes a fun exercise, especially when paired with its sister wine made in American oak.
Appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US

desc: From a mix of vineyards, this tastes of berries, raisins, cooked plums, and baking spices. The tannins are hard and slightly bitter, and there seems to be a hint of residual sugar, perhaps to mitigate the bitterness.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Raspberry jam aromas greet you as the bouquet exudes power: There's bursting fruit, campfire, earth and chocolate rolled into one. The palate is healthy but not overdone; oak is present but not overwhelming. Quite healthy and spunky, and can age. Luca is the private label of Laura Catena.
Appellation: Altos de Mendoza, Mendoza Province, Argentina

desc: A pronounced herb and spice aroma continues in the flavors of this full-bodied and mouth-filling wine. It has a soothing viscosity that carries the spicy grassy notes in a harmonious way.
Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US

desc: With seriously dense tannins, this shows great structure. Rich and full of ripe fruit, it also has a fresh streak that gives it a lift. The structure will allow the wine to age over many years while the fruit and acidity will give it crispness. Drink this impressive wine from 2027.

A complex bouquet of berries, cedar, cinnamon and earth leads into a chewy, full palate of cherries supported by brisk acidity. Young and frisky, it closes with zingy tannins that are a little astringent now, but give it a year or two; there's good fruit here.

Initially closed, a few swirls of the glass releases subtle scents suggesting Spanish Broom, linden blossom, flint and a whisper of orange zest. While the palate is less expressive than the nose, it still offers yellow apple, citrus and mineral alongside crisp acidity. It's still very immature and needs additional time to age.
From the vast sea of statewide Chardonnay out there comes this perfectly acceptable wine. It has peach and apple flavors and some oak, and is creamy and dry.

Full and enticing aromatics of cherry, vanilla and toasted white bread. Soft in the mouth, it shows some of its southern Oregon roots via mild tannins and lower acidity. Emphasizes body and texture over flavors of apple skins and resiny wood.
Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US

desc: Rounded, smooth and fruity, this is an attractive wine. With its light texture and acidity that balance the juicy black fruits, it is ripe while also poised. The aftertaste is fresh and fruity.

wine_name: Lone Madrone 2011 Bailey Ranch Dry Farmed Zinfandel (Paso Robles)
desc: Coming from one of the appellation's most consistent producers, this offers a tight, restrained nose of blackberry and licorice. It's also tight and bright on the palate, with refreshing flavors of black cherries and crushed rocks. An expert balance of tannins and acidity gives the mouth a clean wash.
Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Aromas of rubber, leafy red fruit and herbal raspberry are solid. It's crisp in the mouth, with raspy tannins supporting tight cherry and raspberry flavors. Finishes like it flows, with firm acidity and zest more than richness, leaving a hint of creamy vanilla and heat as it fades away.

This wine is all about its tannic structure. It is powerful, steely with a strong mineral texture to go with the dense black fruits. Complex and still very young, the wine has weight and layers of acidity. The open lagar fermentation brings out extra richness. Drink from 2018.

wine_name: Jean Edwards 2009 Seventy Four - Forty One Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
desc: A big, firm 100% Cab, rich in blackberry jam and black currant flavors, enriched with lots of sweet, smoky oak. It's made in the modern cult style of soft approachability. It might age, but seems best now for sheer luxury.

wine_name: Hartford 1999 Three Jacks Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
desc: Four different clones are separately fermented and then blended to make this unique bottling. An expansive nose shows vibrant pineapple, peach, and orange fruit with lemondrop and butterscotch accents. It's rich and mouthfilling, like a bite of banana cream pie, and turns maybe a bit orangey-sweet. Shy on subtlety, it packs in a lot of juicy flavor.
Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US

desc: A good, classic California Zin, dry, medium-bodied and briary, filled with spicy tobacco, wild cherry and pepper flavors. It's a lot of fun, at a great price. Perfect with barbecue, beef stew, beef tacos, roast pork, chicken cacciatore.

Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Merlot are blended to produce a wine of enormous intensity and personality. You'll get aromas of inky black fruit, barbecue sauce, cola, root beer and black cherry. The wine tastes beautifully smooth and soft in the mouth.
Thin in character, this is a pleasant wine without much style. Light and ready to be drunk immediately.

wine_name: Sagelands 2001 Four Corners Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
desc: This is a really nice Cabernet. It's very oaky, but the acidy structure and sappy, fresh young blackberry fruit provide more than enough counterpoint to all that sweet wood. The tannins are just beautiful. An incredible value in New World Cabernet.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: This wine from Central Italy (made with Cesanese d'Affile grapes) offers a deeply perfumed bouquet of pressed flowers, wild herbs, exotic spice and church incense. It has a profoundly exotic and spicy side (and a brownish hue to its appearance), which could work well with Mexican or Indian dishes.
Dressed up with flashy oak, this medium-bodied wine smells smoky and spicy, tastes oaky, beefy and dark, and has moderate tannins in the texture.

wine_name: Domaines Barons de Rothschild (Lafite) 1998 Los Vascos Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Colchagua Valley)
desc: This evenly balanced Cabernet has a Bordeaux-like profile, with berry and cassis flavors, nicely integrated oak, and a mild herbal, bell pepper note. Shows good fruit for a 1998 wine and some attractive tobacco and earth shadings. Medium weight, it finishes nicely with moderate tannins and some spice-pepper notes. Drinks well now and may improve over two or three years.

wine_name: Krupp Brothers 2014 The Water Witch Stagecoach Vineyard Red (Napa Valley)
desc: This new offering combines Cabernet Sauvignon, Tempranillo, Cabernet Franc and Petit Verdot from the mountain site. The wine is intensely ripe and tart, with rounded edges and an oaky underbelly. Cedar and black currant are the dominant characteristics.
The white sugar and honey sweetness make this a dessert wine, rather than an off-dry white. It's rich in oranges and vanilla, and is a little watery.
Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Luis Felipe Edwards 2010 LFE900 Single Vineyard Red (Colchagua Valley)
desc: Hailing from a vineyard planted 900 meters above sea level, this Syrah-led blend is black as night, gaseous on the nose and loaded with heavy, ripe berry flavors. It's rich, chewy, dense and delivers a truck load's worth of blackberry, boysenberry, prune and chocolate on top of a rugged, brawny, saturated foundation.

wine_name: The Red Square 2006 For The People Sauvignon Blanc (Marlborough)
desc: This charitable endeavor that helps fund student scholarships in Hawkes Bay has yet to really strike gold with any of its wines. This Sauvignon features pleasant herbal and passion fruit shadings but finishes with a touch of sweetness and just lacks zip.

wine_name: Siduri 2012 Bucher Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma County)
desc: The vineyard was made famous by Wiliams Selyem's bottlings. Now Siduri dips in, with excellent results. The vineyard is on Westside Road, a warmer part of the northern valley, and while it shows ripe persimmon and pomegranate fruit flavors, it's generous in acidity. The finish is dry and spicy. A scour of tannins strongly suggests ageability. Begin drink this lovely wine in 2018.
This structured wine has acidity and a broad base of black fruits. It is concentrated and firm, but with the fruitiness of the vintage. Drink this already-attractive wine from 2018.

A unique wine with a distinctive nose of green apples, minerals and Bergamot (think Earl Grey tea). While relatively unevolved and closed now, it still shows lots of earthy complexity, breed and length. This shows just how sophisticated Chardonnay from Oregon can be. Cellar it and you'll get a “charge” out of it in 2 or 3 years.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: Ripe, earthy black-fruit aromas are spicy and a bit lactic from oak, hence, the palate is full and creamy, but with a good acidic cut. Blackberry, herbal spice and cool toasty oak flavors finish warm and plump.
A heavy, sweet rosé, this is made from Mourvèdre, Cinsault and Grenache. The flavors are of raspberries, vanilla and toast.
Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Envy 2008 Nord Vineyard Petite Sirah (Napa Valley)
desc: Big, rich, thick, showing all the hallmarks of a wine that means business. Very great from a Petite Sirah point of view, massively constructed in blackberries, cherries, blueberries, anise, coffee, cocoa and spices, with firm, rich tannins, and the briary, slightly rustic mouthfeel that characterizes the variety. Really good now, with decanting, and should develop in the bottle for many years.

Lots of juicy flavors here. Packed with jammy plum, blackberry and cherry tastes that ooze over the tongue, and it's nicely dry, with no hint of sugar. But those meddlesome tannins are jagged, making for a rough ride.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Marqués de Montañana 2011 Selección Especial Garnacha (Calatayud)
desc: This Garnacha is perfectly good in every way, shape and form. The nose is loaded with bright berry aromas and a hint of mint. The palate feels lively and right, while flavors of raspberry, blackberry and leather lead to a deep, long, slightly hot finish.
Dark from beginning to end, from aromas of espresso and bitter chocolate to a finish of black pepper and earth. In between there's roasted plummy fruit tinged with leafy tobacco and herb notes.

wine_name: Bodegas Fariña 2006 Third Generation Dama de Toro Crianza  (Toro)
desc: Rubbery, floral aromas of raspberry and cherry along with wet cement get this mature Toro wine going. The palate offers fleshy fruit and firm tannins, while the flavor profile brings floral, leafy, leathery flavors in front of a solid, fresh feeling and leafy tasting finish. Drink now.
Designation: Third Generation Dama de Toro Crianza

wine_name: Atalayas de Golbán 2007 Torre de Golbán Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)
desc: Leather and berry aromas are welcoming and veer toward mint. It feels solid and textured, with lightly oaked, earthy flavors of meaty berry and vanilla. It tastes roasted and shows medium intensity on the finish. A good crianza from a marginal vintage.
Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain

desc: A very crisp Chardonnay, with a high level of acidity to go with the white currant and green plum fruits. The wine is fruity and open, while kept tight by an apple skin texture. Screw cap.

wine_name: Zusslin NV Brut Zéro Sparkling (Crémant d'Alsace)
desc: Lively, fruity wine that is fragrant and fresh. Having no sugar and bone dry, it is as crisp as an apple. A bright mousse offers a fine fruity texture and a light, citrus aftertaste.

Red cherry aromas with a touch of smokiness promise well. But the palate is light for a Morgon, bringing out acidity and austere tannins. The acidity comes through the redcurrant flavors, with candy sweetness showing to finish.
A strongly flavored, rather heavy rosé that's almost as full-bodied as a Grenache, which forms half the blend, with Syrah. It shows flavors of cherries and raspberries, and lacks delicacy.
Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US

desc: This powerful wine brings out both the structure and density of wines from the Alto Douro region. It has spice from wood aging, rich tannins and concentrated black fruits. It is a complex, partnering rich fruits with a dry core. The wine will age well, so don't drink before 2021.

This is a Bordeaux-style blend based on the two Cabernets, Sauvignon and Franc. It's made in the modern style, soft, ripe and oaky. Floods the mouth with black cherry and raspberry flavors, sweetened with caramelized oak, and undeniably delicious. However, a combination of high alcohol and excessive softness seems to limit ageability, so enjoy over the next few years.

wine_name: Abbazia di Novacella 2012 Gewürztraminer (Alto Adige Valle Isarco)
desc: Structured and refined, it discloses restrained aromas of white rose and exotic fruit. The rich but lively palate delivers mango, apricot, white peach and grapefruit. It's more polished and less flamboyant than many of its peers.
Appellation: Alto Adige Valle Isarco, Northeastern Italy, Italy

desc: From a major quinta on the south bank of the Douro river at Pinhão, this Port from a great vintage shows sweetness as well as rich tannins, intensity and layers of black fruits. Its structure emphasizes the initial fruitiness of the wine while promising plenty of aging. Drink from 2025.

This is a rounded Port, showing layers of black fruits, ripe tannins and spice. At the same time, it does have a solid structure that will allow it to age. The acidity comes through at the end. Drink from 2028.
This is a crisp wine, full of acidity. It holds the potential of crisp green and citrus fruits that are developing. A nutty edge contrasts with the tense acidity. Drink from late 2017.

wine_name: Ets Thunevin 2017 Le Clos du Beau-Père  (Pomerol)
desc: Rich with swaths of ripe fruit, this wine is also structured. Dense Merlot gives it power, bringing in black-fruit flavors and acidity. The wine will be ready from 2022.

This is a pure, aesthetic wine, delicately outlined and shaped. With its citrus flavors, crisp lines and tight, taut acidity, it shows both great minerality and a sharp final focus on fruit and structure. Age this wine, and don't drink before 2017.

wine_name: Domaine Marchand-Grillot 2015 Petite Chapelle Premier Cru  (Gevrey-Chambertin)
desc: This perfumed wine is rich but so well judged that its elegance dominates. It conveys some wood flavors but the richness of the fruit compensates. Delicious black-cherry and black-plum flavors are balanced with acidity that gives a great lift at the end. Drink from 2023.

Fermented in open lagars, this wine is luscious with wonderful depth of black fruit flavor, spice and acidity. It has hints of wood, although these are already well integrated into the ripe fruit. Age this wine for at least 3–4 years.
89-91 Concentrated wood aromas, although on the palate fine, tannic black fruits show through the toast. Will be rich and juicy.

This vineyard has a long, distinguished history, even before it passed into Jackson Family's hands. It's a great mountain property, yielding focused, concentrated flavors of tropical fruits that are well oaked. There's also a firm minerality. One of the few Chards that can age. Better 2011–2013.

wine_name: Langtry 2007 Lillie Langtry Estate Sauvignon Blanc (Guenoc Valley)
desc: Shows too much of that pyrazine, feline aroma and flavor, which makes it offensive. If you can get past that, you'll find lemons, grapefruits, pineapples and guavas.
Appellation: Guenoc Valley, Lake County, California, US

desc: A pungent, grassy wine, layered with green pepper and herbal notes. Leaner than most 2005 Marlborough Sauvignons, finishing with sharp strokes of lime and grapefruit. Imported by Paterno Wines International.

wine_name: Stag's Leap Wine Cellars 2004 Chardonnay (Napa Valley)
desc: Kind of heavy and dull, with earth and mineral flavors breaking into citrus and green apples. Finishes bone dry and tart in acids. Call it Chablisian.

wine_name: Nickel & Nickel 2015 C.C. Ranch Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)
desc: From a site on the eastern edges of the appellation, this wine offers robust aromas of pencil shavings, cedar and dried herb. Black peppercorn, vanilla and black currant flavors make for a savory and fruity palate that is supported by a grip of tannins. Enjoy 2025–2030.

Although it kicks off on the stewy, baked side of the fence, airing reveals good fruit and ample wood; indeed, there's brandied cherry, vanilla and chocolate to ponder. Long on the finish, albeit a finish that's one-note simple. A little stark in terms of feel.

Fresh and light aromas of lemongrass, Pink Lady apples, guava soda and a hint of pineapple make for a slightly tropical but clean approach to this bottling. It's fresh on the sip with spritzy acidity and more tropical flavors of guava, mango, pineapple and tuberose.
Despite plenty of weight in the mouth, this wine's simple apple and lime flavors are surprisingly crisp, turning nearly sour-lemony on the finish. Imported by Walca International.

wine_name: Kathryn Kennedy 2004 Twenty-Seven Blanc de Blanc Chardonnay (Santa Cruz Mountains)
desc: Just-cracked, yeasty sourdough bread and dried lemon-skin aromas float off of this bottle-aged sparkler from an esteemed, longtime producer. Her winemaker son named this wine in honor of her birth year. An oxidative warmth gives bready depth to the palate, which shows lots of toast and lemon marmalade flavors.
Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Full and open on the nose, showing fresh herbs, crushed berries and damp earth. A fruity wine, with plum and cherry carried on a chewy, clean frame. Good and generous, with just enough complexity.

This is a blend from a number of parcels previously owned by monks (who understood the location of good vineyards) in the hamlet of Blagny situated just back from the main Meursault vineyards. The wine is rich with a subtle hint of toastiness and honey along with minerality and bright green and white stone fruits. Drink from 2020.

Rooty/ berry aromas come with a big heaping of mature earth tones and cool cola accents. This is ripped with acidity, which makes sense since 2008 was a chilly, wet year. Bold berry, plum, cherry and tobacco flavors finish easy and smooth; drink through 2020.

Clean, classic Cabernet aromas do a good job of inviting you in. Cassis, vanilla and herbs mix nicely. The deep-purple color accurately announces the big blackberry flavor. Underneath is some pleasant oak. It finishes mildly hot, but overall it's smooth.

wine_name: Pierre Gimonnet et Fils 2009 Cuvée Fleuron Premier Cru Blanc de Blancs Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
desc: This is a serious wine, with its mineral texture and tangy structure. It has plenty of apple and zingy orange flavors. But the main thrust at this stage is of a wine poised for considerable aging. Fresh and still tight, it needs several years. Drink from 2018.
Designation: Cuvée Fleuron Premier Cru Blanc de Blancs Brut

wine_name: Domaine Gresser 2014 Kastelberg Grand Cru Riesling (Alsace)
desc: A very shy closed nose gives little away but the palate reveals all. A beautifully lithe and fluid synthesis of ripe and tart orchard fruits is leavened by bright citrus, green pear, Cox's apple and pure ripe Amalfi lemon. There also is a fine hint of discreet herbal lift—chamomile and chervil can be glimpsed here and there. What an aromatic, statuesque beauty. Alluring now but absolutely certain to become spectacular with some age. The finish is totally dry, aromatic and long. Drink 2017–2037.

Oak dominates this wine, which is all about smoky buttered toast, butterscotch and caramel. Somewhere underneath all that is a pretty good Chardonnay, dry and crisp, with tropical fruit, peach and citrus flavors.

The strong suit here is elegance and grace: Light stone fruit and green apple aromas mingle seamlessly with drying mineral, almost chalk-like tones. The wine is somewhat neutral in the mouth but has clean, sharp angles and an absolutely pristine mouthfeel.
Appellation: Fiano di Avellino, Southern Italy, Italy

desc: This renowned Wairarapa winery's Chardonnay is nothing short of a class act. With poise and length, it delicately weaves together notes of melon, ground ginger, honeysuckle and minerals. In the mouth, the satiny texture is buoyed by tangy fruit and crackling acidity, backed by oak. One of the best in New Zealand, with a long and happy life in front of it. Drink now until at least 2035.

Made with 40% Cabernet Sauvignon, 40% Merlot and 20% Cabernet Franc, this offers aromas of ripe blackberry, bell pepper and a hint of coconut. The rich palate doles out black-currant jam, licorice and a touch of espresso alongside polished velvety tannins. Drink through 2022.
This easy blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Montepulciano  and Alicante opens with a bright cherry note and slightly bitter tones of spice and almond skin. The palate is smoothly textured and rich.
The aromas start off lightly toasty, leading to notes of ripe peach and pineapple. Full bodied, textured, creamy fruit flavors follow, lingering on the extended finish.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: This well-made wine has polished flavors of currants, herbs and spices, elaborated with smoky oak. The tannins are lush and sweet. It's so well structured that you wish it were more concentrated.

wine_name: Château Branas Grand Poujeaux 2015 Barrel Sample  (Moulis-en-Médoc)
desc: 92–94. Barrel Sample. Generous and full bodied, a black plum note and soft tannins give this wine its rounded character. Oak tones and the dry tannins are lingering under fruitiness of this wine.
Aromas of black cherry and white chocolate lead the way for flavors of raspberry, vanilla, espresso and sage. This well-constructed wine offers silky tannins and a soft pleasing finish.
The Muscadelle in this wine makes it so attractive. It gives it a perfumed character, as well as enhancing the lively citrus fruits. Lightly herbal, the wine is ready to drink.

Soft peach and nectarine aromas meet with grapefruit-laced créme anglaise on the balanced nose of this bottling. There's an oily presence to the palate, where tropical mango and banana-cream flavors show in a reserved style.
Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Vintner Luigi Rubino has crafted a spectacular Malvasia Bianca that bears rich and tangy aromas of peach and citrus, followed by silky smoothness and creamy, exotic fruit.

wine_name: L'Ecole No. 41 2006 Seven Hills Vineyard Estate Perigee Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
desc: From the oldest vines in the Seven Hills vineyard, this Bordeaux blend is 56% Cabernet Sauvignon, 34% Merlot and 10% Cabernet Franc. It's dusty, earthy and complex, with strong scents and accents of coffee, chicory and dark chocolate. Lush, layered and seductive, it displays rich black fruits, firm acids, ripe tannins and fine balance throughout.
Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: A light, crisp wine with the freshest of red berry fruits, embedded in tight acidity and a soft, fruity aftertaste. This is a great apéritif drink for a warm day. Screwcap.

wine_name: Foursight 2007 Charles Vineyard All In Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
desc: Delicious now for its rich array of black cherry jam, raspberry tart, mocha, cola, anise and vanilla-cedar flavors, wrapped into an easy, silky mouthfeel. Feels elegant and good, and probably best now through 2011.
Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US

desc: Rich and powerful, with firm tannins, this chunky, muscular red would pair well with burgers or steaks off the grill. Hints of herb and leather accent the ripe cherry fruit. Drink now–2016.

wine_name: Château la Croix de l'Esperance 2003  Lussac Saint-Émilion
desc: Taking advantage of the very ripe grapes of 2003, Bernard Magrez's winemakers pulled all the richness out of the fruit and into this intensely sweet, dark wine, with its black plums and fig flavors. The wood is all around this fruit, dense and spicy.

wine_name: Mark Ryan 2012 Wild Eyed Syrah (Red Mountain)
desc: Hailing from Ciel du Cheval and Force Majeure vineyards, this aromatic wine offers pomegranate, dried leaves, mocha and crushed flowers. It's luxuriously creamy in feel with abundant red fruit flavors.
Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Soft and round, with a big mouthfeel. The flavors are of fresh white fruits, very soft. There is just a touch of almonds, and some oxidation.

Made predominantly with Chardonnay and partly fermented in oak, this elegant wine unfurls with aromas of chamomile flower, Golden Delicious apple, Mediterranean herb, honey and a whiff of toast. The vibrant palate offers white grapefruit, crisp apple, toasted hazelnut and lemon drop. It's well balanced, with bright acidity.

wine_name: Salentein 2016 Salentein Barrel Selection Malbec-Cabernet Sauvignon-Cabernet Franc Red (Uco Valley)
desc: Ripe berry aromas include a desiccated hint of raisin, while this Malbec blend feels flush and juicy, with clarity and balance. Plum, cassis and berry flavors include a complex and welcome note of salt, while this keeps up the pace on a racy finish.
Designation: Salentein Barrel Selection Malbec-Cabernet Sauvignon-Cabernet Franc

wine_name: Soléna 2015 Grande Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
desc: This is ready to drink, quite pleasant, though it leans a bit generic in flavor. Light berry fruit comes with hints of cola and a green streak. The finish turns tannic and lets those stemmy flavors abide.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

wine_name: Elements by Artesa 2007 Elements by Artesa Red (Napa County-Sonoma County)
desc: This is a good, somewhat rustic wine to drink now. It's full bodied and dry, with cherry-berry, tobacco and spice flavors.
Appellation: Napa County-Sonoma County, Napa-Sonoma, California, US

wine_name: Erath 2007 Battle Creek Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
desc: Among the many single-vineyard offerings from Erath, the Battle Creek is distinguished by a particular smokiness, and has a restrained yet powerful red fruit core with excellent persistence. Though pale in color, it is not lacking for flavor or even concentration. Burgundy lovers note—this is sure to please you, but you have to pay attention.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

wine_name: Chateau Lafayette Reneau 2012 Barrel Fermented Chardonnay (Finger Lakes)
desc: Smoke and charred wood accent fresh lemon and apple on this slightly off-dry Chardonnay. Buttery and slick with glycerine, it finishes moderately long with a reedy, herbaceous tone.
Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US

wine_name: I Balzini 2013 Green Label Red (Colli della Toscana Centrale)
desc: Fresh and fragrant, this blend of Sangiovese and 15% Mammolo opens with scents of wild berries, blue flowers, tilled soil and a whiff of kitchen spices. The easy-drinking palate doles out juicy wild cherries, black raspberries, cinnamon and a hint of clove alongside silky tannins. Drink through 2016.
Appellation: Colli della Toscana Centrale, Tuscany, Italy

desc: This nicely balanced and refined Chardonnay offers pear, pineapple and faint peach aromas. On the palate it is spicy with oak and pear flavors. Finishes spicy with a citrusy zing.
Appellation: Hunter Valley, New South Wales, Australia

desc: The high-tone fruit aromas work here, lifting the otherwise dark and heady notes of mulled berries, cherry pie filling, cured meat and sweet smoke. Balanced and ready to drink now with medium weight and dusty tannins. The finish shows nice evolution from fruit to earthy tobacco and finally coffee.
This is a better wine than Maclean's '01, riper and richer. It shows blackberry, cassis and oak flavors, and a good structure. Still, it could use greater concentration.

When Andre Lurton bought Couhins in 1970, he followed a long-established Bordeaux tradition and added his name to the name of the property. This is a delicious, grassy wine, 100% Sauvignon Blanc, with flavors of pink grapefruit, along with some spice from wood aging. There is firm acidity to the finish.

wine_name: Domaine Arnoux Père et Fils 2016 Les Beaumonts  (Chorey-lès-Beaune)
desc: This perfumed wine is ripe with cherry flavors and layers of acidity, with a balanced texture. The wine comes from the village of Chorey on the flat land close to Beaune. With its tannic structure and fruitiness it has a good future for the next few years and will be ready to drink from 2021.

wine_name: Franciscan 2000 Oakville Estate Cuvee Sauvage Chardonnay (Carneros)
desc: Incredibly rich and toasty. Opens with a blast of charry oak, vanilla and caramel. Underlying fruit aromas range from lemons to apples, to peaches and tropical fruits. Drinks full-bodied and powerful, with a creamy texture and vibrant fruit. A sweet-sour note of lees shows up on the finish. —S.H.

wine_name: Armanino Family Cellars 2013 The Pintail Pinot Noir (Napa Valley)
desc: There's something mushroomy and feral about this wine, which finishes with sour cherry.

wine_name: Domaines Devillard 2011 Domaine des Perdrix Les Terres Blanches Premier Cru  (Nuits-St.-Georges)
desc: From one of the rare Chardonnay vineyards in Nuits-St-Georges comes this delicious, fruity, perfumed wine. Apples, quince and hints of yellow fruits are all present, along with a tighter texture and balanced acidity. Keep for a few years and drink from 2016.
Designation: Domaine des Perdrix Les Terres Blanches Premier Cru

desc: Hints of cedar add spice and warmth to aromas of ripe red plums and cherries on this sprightly Cabernet Franc. The palate is tart with cranberry acidity but builds in richness and body, finishing with a fringe of velvety tannins.
Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US

desc: Nuts, sweet figs and spice come together in this delicious wine. It has great freshness as well as the concentrated wood character of a 20-year-old. A great final balance.

wine_name: Sans Wine Co 2018 Poor Ranch Vineyard Rosé of Zinfandel (Mendocino County)
desc: This natural-type wine smells quite earthy and a bit vinegary, but it delivers good, rich fig and peach flavors on the palate, and an appreciable sense of heft and length.
Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US

wine_name: Finca Patagonia 2013 Grand Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon-Syrah (Maule Valley)
desc: Toasty oak, coffee and rooty berry aromas feed into a full, fleshy but still fresh palate. Black-fruit flavors come with an accent of black coffee, while this blend of 65% Cabernet Sauvignon and 35% Syrah finishes with toasty mocha and herbal berry flavors.

wine_name: Grant Burge 2001 Barossa Vines Chardonnay (Barossa Valley)
desc: More interesting to smell than to taste, the aromas burst with apple, nectarine, straw and clover honey, but the flavors are simple apple and citrus. Finishes short and lemony.

wine_name: Nino Franco 2015 Primo Franco Dry  (Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore)
desc: Aromas of fragrant white flower, chopped herb and white stone fruit jump out of the glass while the creamy palate presents juicy yellow peach, mature green apple and a note of candied nectarine zest. A soft foaming mousse accompanies the rich flavors.

A crowd-pleasing Chardonnay from Wente, working in the Monterey area, the result all caramel, vanilla and lemon-lime with a sweet tropical chaser on the finish. The oak is subtle. This wine will pair deliciously with a range of food, particularly chicken and seafood.
Appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US

desc: El Vegro delivers a bright Soave Classico with a golden hue and aromas of exotic fruit, peach and caramel. There's a ripe quality to the fruit that adds weight and waxy heaviness to the mouthfeel.

wine_name: Buehler 2007 Papa's Knoll Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
desc: A really wonderful Cabernet, clearly grown well and well made. It has that plush, rich feeling you want in a Cabernet Sauvignon, with deliciously ripe blackberry, black currant, cassis and dark chocolate flavors. Terrific now, and should age for 4–6 years, if not longer.

wine_name: José Maria da Fonseca 2012 José de Sousa Red (Alentejano)
desc: This is an open juicy and fruity wine. It has soft tannins and perfumed acidity that is already integrated into the structure of the wine. With blackberry and red plum flavors, it is easy and generous, ready to drink now.
The 2005 Pinot Noir from Honeywood is a dead ringer for—guess what!—the 2004 Pinot Noir from the same winery. Soft entry, herbal and somewhat stemmy mid-palate, tannic, slightly hot finish.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: Citrus, cut grass, white almond skin, peach and melon all play a roll in the aromatic intensity of this white wine. In the mouth, it offers medium creaminess with more peach on the close.

The glorious aromatics of the ripest oranges play on the nose. There even is a slight hint of candied peel. The palate is opulent with fruit expression but held in check by lovely ripe lemon freshness. The palate is concentrated and has lots of energetic direction. An earthy edge grounds things beautifully. Lasting and lovely.

Neuburger is the grape variety, a cross between Weissburgunder (Pinot Blanc) and Sylvaner. The result is a richly textured white with lovely floral notes on the nose and flavors of honey, ripe peaches and citrus. Finishes soft, with hints of dried spices. Imported by Winemonger.com.

wine_name: City Winery of New York 2012 Brut Nature Sparkling (North Fork of Long Island)
desc: This blanc de blancs offers toasted brioche, citrus cream and drawn butter aromas. It's rich and broad on the palate, with a balanced perlage that carries crisp yellow apple, citrus rind and bitter almond skin flavors.
Appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US

desc: Oily, floral aromas are typical of this variety. A round but flat palate shows modest acidity, while this tastes lightly oxidized and of lychee and nectarine. The finish is flat.

wine_name: Château de Seguin 2001 Cuvee Prestige 2000 Bordeaux Blanc  (Bordeaux Blanc)
desc: Any shellfish would be a great partner to this wine. It is full of ripe, citrus aromas while the palate has freshness, crispness and a refreshing green aftertaste.

wine_name: Schröder & Schÿler 2017 Chartron la Fleur  (Bordeaux Blanc)
desc: Aged for a few months in tank before bottling, this wine captures the herbal and ripe green-fruit character of Bordeaux Sauvignon Blanc. Its light acidity, fruitiness and crisp aftertaste all come together well. Drink now.

Freshness is the calling card here. This wine is so crystalline-clear with palate-cleansing minerality that it's irresistible. Green apples and light citrus flavors combine in a stylish effort made for near-term enjoyment.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: Light in color and delicately structured, this red picks up weight and body as it opens, revealing layers of bright orange and strawberry. It has grippy tannin and a length of baking spice on the finish.
Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US

desc: A dry, firm wine, full of its tannins. The juiciness underneath promises black currant brightness in six months to a year. With ample acidity and a fine sense of structure, this wine is concentrated and rich.

wine_name: Terrazas de Los Andes 2001 Afincado Las Compuertas Vineyard Malbec (Mendoza)
desc: Boasting plum, bitter chocolate and some earth, this is a fairly full Malbec, but not one that shows off the best this winery can do. For that, wait for the 2002 and '03 vintages, which are measurably better. Here, however, there's bulky fruit, coffee notes and some woody spice that are more than acceptable.

wine_name: Binyamina 2009 Reserve Late Harvest Cluster Select Gewürztraminer (Galilee)
desc: This is a stunning, well-balanced late-harvest selection that's sure to be a welcome addition to any dessert course. Notes of ginger and sweet baking spice lift the baked-apple, peach and apricot-preserve fruit core. A kiss of honeyed sweetness and a soft, candied orange-peel flavor lingers on the close. Ample acidity keeps the palate fresh and lifted.

wine_name: Rutherford Hill 2003 Rosé of Merlot (Napa Valley)
desc: Seems pricey for a rather thin, inert wine. A flavorful blush Merlot from Napa would be a good thing, but this one is just too diluted.

Tastes so softly decadent, so rich in jam and chocolate flavors, that it's no surprise to learn the alcohol on this Merlot is a hefty 16.2% by volume. It's almost Port-like, but the finish is dry and clean. It's not for long aging, but with the right foods—Mexican mole beef or lamb comes to kind—this is a good marriage.

The shy nose on this wine leads onto a dry, fresh palate. It shows a flowing body with a gentle texture. Despite the general ease, there is a little warmth on the bright finish. This cuvée is also bottled under the Tramier et Fils brand.

A nose of raspberry, violet and iodine sets the scene for delightful flavors of blueberry, blackberry, mocha and lavender with a touch of brambles. Long-lasting tannings continue into a white-chocolate and strawberry finish.

wine_name: Alta Cima 2006 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Lontué Valley)
desc: Coffee, roasted meat, toasted nuts and other dark aromas set up a slightly fiery palate with mildly medicinal tasting red-fruit flavors. Sweet and dark notes of cotton candy and espresso, respectively, mix on the finish.

wine_name: Terre Rouge 2014 High Slopes Syrah (Sierra Foothills)
desc: This wine's intense berry aromas are followed by equally deep flavors, as its meaty, earthy, spicy nuances develop with each sip. It has complexity, concentration, a very smooth texture and that certain wild element that's attractive in Syrah.
Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US

desc: Floral in jasmine flowers, this wine aromatically could trick one into thinking it's Sauvignon Blanc until more developed layers of anise, apple, lime and peach come to the fore. The backbone of supportive oak adds complexity.
Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US

desc: This warm, ripe wine is open and ready to drink. With its bold red fruit and generous, well-integrated tannins, it's made for barbecues. Drink now.

Very fresh and refreshing aromas of honeysuckle blossoms, seared apple, lemongrass and kiwi hit the nose on this wine by James Ontiveros. The palate shows a bit of ripe apple flesh, but trends more toward sour citrus rinds. It's a very clean, crisp wine.
Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: José Maria da Fonseca 2000 Domini Plus Red (Douro)
desc: This is one of two wines (and a Port) which are the product of a joint venture between Setúbal-based Domingos Soares Franco of J.M. da Fonseca and Cristiano van Zeller, a leading Port producer. It is a powerful, black-fruited wine with balanced new wood and tarry fruit flavors. Still young, its exudes potential with its layers of richness.  The relatively high alcohol (14.5%) is held in check by the power of the fruit. —R.V.

wine_name: Pacific Rim 2008 Solstice Vineyard Riesling (Yakima Valley)
desc: Flinty, with dense citrus rind phenolics, and great length. There are subtle traces of honey, lingering threads that suggest everything from apples to papaya.
Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Direct and concentrated, this wine is powered by tannins and a firm texture. Dense, it has the potential for plenty of fruit as it matures. That will take time, because this impressive wine is powered by its structure. Wait until 2028.

wine_name: Chateau Ste. Michelle 2017 Canoe Ridge Estate Chardonnay (Horse Heaven Hills)
desc: The aromas offer notes of baked apple, crayon, vanilla, pineapple and spice. Compact fruit and barrel flavors follow. The style gets a bit in front of the fruit, but there's still enjoyment to be had.
Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Bugay 2007 The Empress Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
desc: There's a good wine in here, but it needs some time to escape the cage of hard tannins and primary fruit. Floods the mouth with blackberry pie, crème de cassis and sweet, vanilla oak flavors that are just itching for a good 5–7 years in the cellar.

Rich and ripe in fruit, this polished young Cabernet shows intense blackberry, cassis and sweet cedar flavors, wrapped into firm tannins. Flashy and opulent, it should provide good drinking over the next six years.

wine_name: Alain Jaume et Fils 2018 Clos de Sixte Red (Lirac)
desc: Whispers of smoke and tobacco lend earthen complexities to ripe but pristine blackberry and cherry. It's a bold, voluptuous wine framed in firm, slightly charry tannins but elegant through a long finish. Ready now but should hold well through 2027.

wine_name: Château l'Espérance 2015 Cuvée Trois Frères  (Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux)
desc: Red berry aromas signal an attractive wine that is fragrant and fruity yet has enough tannins to age. Drink from 2019.
Appellation: Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France

wine_name: Domaine Rieflé 2008 Steinert Grand Cru Riesling (Alsace)
desc: Orange and mandarin flavors mark this warm, full-bodied wine. It's forward and fruity, showing a sweeter character, with vanilla and spice tones. Drink soon.

wine_name: Jones of Washington 2006 Cabernet Sauvignon (Wahluke Slope)
desc: From estate-grown fruit, this adds Merlot, Sangiovese and Syrah to the Cab. The net result is a diffuse wine with no varietal character. Tannins are hard and bitter, and the fruit seems to be hiding.
Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Bright cherryade flavors give an attractive, herbal character. It's not sweet, although there is a suggestion of this. It finishes soft and round, and the wine is not likely to develop further.
Dark in color, this soft, leathery Zin offers tangents of blackberry, chocolate and espresso within a heavy-handed package of serious fruit and weight.
Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US

desc: This smells like fresh pavement at first, with gritty black-fruit and burnt leaf notes. The palate feels edgy, with a spotty red-fruit flavor that's matched with notes of resiny oak and vanilla. It finishes in a similar fashion. Novo Imports and Aidil Wines & Liquors.

Light lemon butter meets with Key-lime pith and a steely minerality on the nose of this bottling from the pioneering property that is now owned by Bill Foley. It's very light on the palate, with touches of citrus, apples and cider-like spice, proving easy to sip.
Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Ledda 2014 Tenuta Monte Santu Ruiu Red (Isola dei Nuraghi)
desc: Made with native grapes Cannonau and Muristellu, this opens with aromas of underbrush, tilled soil, leather and tobacco leaf. Smooth and full bodied, the rounded palate offers dried black cherry, licorice and pipe tobacco alongside fine-grained tannins. It closes on a graphite note and the warmth of alcohol that throws it slightly off balance.
Appellation: Isola dei Nuraghi, Sicily & Sardinia, Italy

wine_name: Compton Family 2016 Alpine Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
desc: Firm, ripe flavors of plum and cherry combine with barrel notes from 18 months in French oak. Highlights of sandalwood, mocha and a touch of toast add length and interest to the finish. Drink now through the mid-2020s.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

wine_name: Louis Guntrum 2015 Nierstein Bergkirche Kabinett Riesling (Rheinhessen)
desc: Hints of honey and caramel lend warmth to this ripe, unusually robust kabinett. Voluptuous body and haulting acidity augment its bold, expansive mouthfeel. A fringe of astringency lends some structure to the finish.

wine_name: The Dot 2016 Austrian Pepper Grüner Veltliner (Niederösterreich)
desc: A salty hint of yeast and fresh, green apple and pear appear on the nose. The slender palate is enlivened by lemon brightness and slight spritz. Cheeky green fruit and white pepper tingle everywhere, making for an easy but refreshing drink.

Dense and textured, this is a powerful, complex wine. It's layered with honey and botrytis, and a concentrated fruitiness with flavors of apricots and creamed pears. There is a great sense of freshness on the finish.

wine_name: Domaine Dominique Gruhier 2011 Côte de Grisey Cuvée Juliette  (Bourgogne Epineuil)
desc: With spice and dark coffee flavors, this wine shows some wood aging. It also has considerable acidity and the brightest strawberry fruit. Lively and fragrant at the end, it can be drunk now.

Here's a wine that begs a pairing with a truffle dish: black truffle Cornish hen or creamy risotto with white truffle flakes would do the trick. Cannubi San Lorenzo's aromas include spice, cherry, cola, white licorice, white mushroom and smoked ham. This is a beautiful wine with a firm, determined but elegant finish.

wine_name: Andrew Murray 2019 Esperance Curtis Vineyard Rosé (Santa Ynez Valley)
desc: Very brisk and yet immensely comforting on the nose, this bottling offers judicious aromas of strawberry-banana bubblegum and crushed seashell. The palate is tightly woven, allowing light brushes of peach and melon to ride the zesty acidity that carries deep into the finish.
Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Presqu'ile 2012 Steiner Creek Vineyard Pinot Noir (San Luis Obispo County)
desc: Coming from an extreme coastal vineyard three miles north of Cambria, this cool-climate study offers aromas of blistered cherry tomatoes, Eastern European goulash spices and crushed peppercorns of all colors. It's fresh and lively on the palate, with hints of rose and tart raspberry. At the same time, it's quite vegetal, with green notes that will evolve into more balanced umami flavors from 2017 to 2022.
Appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US

desc: This wine offers classic Napa Valley richness and fruit-forwardness, while also maintaining an underlying elegance of balance. Apple and honey star on the nose and palate, complementing each other, becoming more developed in the glass as they go.

wine_name: Comte Henri d'Assay 2018 Comte Henry Commune de St-Andelain Argiles à Silex  (Pouilly-Fumé)
desc: From flint and clay soil at the high point of the appellation, this wine is textured, bright with bold white fruits behind a tautly mineral texture. The wine will benefit from further aging to bring out its full potential. Drink from 2021.
Designation: Comte Henry Commune de St-Andelain Argiles à Silex

desc: Nice flavors, with blackberries, pepper, licorice and beef jerky, but the wine is a little sweet and way too soft for balance.
Intense in mulled spices and juicy blue and black berry, this is a smooth, approachable and likable wine. Medium bodied, it will play well at the table, providing a chocolaty note at its end.

wine_name: Librandi 2008 Magno Megonio Red (Val di Neto)
desc: Magno Megonico, from Calabria in the deep south of Italy, is an edgy, sharp wine with a pointed vein of acidity that carries through the end. That natural freshness and 14% alcohol helps underline the wine's aromas of raspberry and forest fruit. Pair this wine with a fatty food cooked with butter or cheese.
Appellation: Val di Neto, Southern Italy, Italy

wine_name: Reustle 2013 Prayer Rock Vineyards Talitha Cumi Bloc Sauvignon Blanc (Umpqua Valley)
desc: Unmistakably Sauvignon Blanc, it carries notes of herbs, citrus and guava. It's lightly spritzy and drinks dry with mouthwatering citrus flavors. Try it with shellfish.
Designation: Prayer Rock Vineyards Talitha Cumi Bloc
Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US

wine_name: Bethel Heights 2013 Aeolian Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)
desc: Generous black-cherry fruit anchors this barrel-aged wine that remains tartly acidic, with pretty accents of toast and mocha. Focused, young and fresh, it should drink optimally 2018–2028.
Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

wine_name: Dominio IV 2013 Mulberry Street Vitae Springs Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
desc: Capturing the elegant aromas of both vineyard and vintage, this tickles the nose with rose petal and spring strawberry scents. Raspberry notes join the mix in the mouth, feeling clean and refreshing, though more delicate than powerful.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: Red in color, with neutral aromas of red apple skins. The palate is sticky and weighty, and the taste is akin to fruit punch with tangerine on the side. Tastes o.k. but is too full, chunky and heavy to be refreshing
This is a pleasantly plum-perfumed Mourvèdre that's straightforward in approach and flavor. Just slightly chewy, the wine shows a burst of mocha on the finish.
Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US

desc: From one of the properties owned by the Chanfreau family of neighboring Château Fonréaud, Chemin-Royal is dominated by new wood flavors that give the wine a toasty edge. At this stage, it is difficult to taste the fruit, but the wine has weight, which should develop through the tannins.

wine_name: Chateau Ste. Michelle 2017 Artist Series Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
desc: Cabernet Sauvignon accounts for 56% of this wine, with the rest Merlot (39%) and smidgen of Malbec and Cabernet Franc. The aromas are brooding, with notes of barrel spice, dark chocolate, dried and black cherry. Creamy fruit and barrel flavors follow, showing an appealing texture. Coffee and raspberry notes linger on the finish. It's a complete charmer.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Fowles Wine 2017 Ladies Who Shoot Their Lunch Riesling (Victoria)
desc: This is a solid Riesling that's blended with a touch of wild fermented Pinot Gris for added complexity. The nose is delicate and multifaceted in notes of flower blossoms, tangerine, apple, crushed stone and a little honeycomb. The palate is dry and poised with a wet stone and chalk quality to the texture and a tangerine tang at the finish. Drink now–2028.

wine_name: Friedrich-Wilhelm-Gymnasium NV Fritz Willi Frizzante Riesling (Mosel)
desc: This frizzante, or delicately sparkling wine, is a fun, zippy alternative to Riesling sekt. Bright apple, lemon and quince notes are forward and fresh, offering easy quaffability and soft, yielding effervescence. Drink now through 2020.

Tangy lemon zest comes through strongly in this wine. Its acidity is reinforced by a mineral texture that adds complexity. This fifth-generation Fournier family wine has a full-bodied feel and is still young. Let it calm down a little and drink from late 2019.
Vegetal, with prune and syrup aromas. It is sour and simultaneously sweet. For most folks, it won't cut the mustard.

wine_name: Laroche 2003 La Croix Chevalière Red (Vin de Pays d'Oc)
desc: An impressive wine, a blend of Syrah, Mourvèdre and Cabernet Sauvignon, this is only produced in the best vintages at Michel Laroche's Mas la Chevalière.
