They're backed by dried mint, sage and peppery spice, and a slightly synthetic, perfumed soap note. Things improve on the palate, which is granular in texture, with a bright line of acidity and a firm grip of fine savory tannins. Drink 2021–2028.

wine_name: Lamoreaux Landing 2008 Estate Bottled Chardonnay (Finger Lakes)
desc: Juicy, freshly pressed apple flavors in this dry, medium-bodied Chardonnay gain savory components amid layers of toasted wood, coconut and sawdust. Bright acidity and hints of fresh grass and herbs add refinement and refreshment.
Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US

wine_name: Balboa 2008 Mirage Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
desc: There's real concentration evident in this modestly priced Cabernet from Balboa. It's got density and grip—the Cabernet fruit is sappy and solid, with plenty of cassis and black cherry flavor, substantial tannins, and a lick of licorice. This feels and tastes like a pricier bottle.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Quite yellow in the glass, this atypical blend of 40% Viognier, 30% Chardonnay, 20% Roussanne and 10% Grenache Blanc begins with aromas of boiled lemons, dried mango and butterscotch. The flavors blend riper mango with sour orange, proving both rich and tart.
Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Summerland 2013 Bien Nacido Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)
desc: Lavish aromas of black cherry pie, clove, vanilla, warm brioche, almond croissant and loamy earth show on the nose of this bottling by Etienne Terlinden from the historic vineyard. Hearty and wild blackberry flavors mix with thyme, tarragon, juniper and black tea on the palate.
Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US

desc: An entirely varietal wine from the heart the appellation, this red is burly in dried herb, turned earth, nutmeg and clove. Thick tannins wrap around a density of caramel, dark chocolate and licorice, offering structure and graceful integration.

wine_name: Noble Tree 2014 Wicker Sham Ranch Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
desc: Inky color and intense leather, chocolate and smoke notes provide context and character to this inexpensive offering, which finishes with ripe, jammy blackberry and brown sugar flavors.

From Tygerberg, this attractive Cabernet offers smoked sausage and spice on the nose and a wonderful balance of pepper, smoke and juicy fruit on the palate. It's assertive and ageable but good now. A hint of restrained minerality means it will pair well with myriad foods.

wine_name: David Girard 2005 Coeur du Terroir Blanc White (El Dorado)
desc: What a complex, delicious wine this is. A blend of five Rhône varieties, mainly Roussanne, it has the richness and mouthfeel of a barrel-fermented Chardonnay, but a very different taste. The peach, citrus, buttercup flower, honeydew and cantaloupe flavors finish with creamy, cashew butter richness.
Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US

wine_name: Yalumba 2008 The Y Series Rosé Sangiovese (South Australia)
desc: This wine's strawberry and watermelon fruit is tinged with a hint of tobacco, but the emphasis remains on the fruit from start to finish. Crisp, clean and fresh, it seems completely dry to the taste.

Quite dark in color, with a dark-edged flavor profile as well. Charry, smoky qualities frame black plum and cherry notes that give way to herb and spice flavors. Bright on the finish, with an herbal, slighty astringent edge at the end.
Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US

wine_name: Adams Bench 2009 Artz and Shaw Red Mountain Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)
desc: This two-vineyard blend of two-thirds Merlot and one-third Cabernet Sauvignon is a well-balanced mix of brambly berry flavors, with details of leaf and clean earth. Both vineyards are well established and are located in prime Cabernet country on Red Mountain.
Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Von Strasser 2005 Cabernet Sauvignon (Diamond Mountain District)
desc: The winery's basic Cab, with no vineyard designation, shares the qualities of the more expensive bottlings. It's dry and tannic and ultraconcentrated in varietal character, with explosive cassis, cherry and new oak flavors. Impresses now for its luxurious mouthfeel, and should develop through 2013.
Appellation: Diamond Mountain District, Napa, California, US

desc: This is a lovely, dry example of Marlborough Pinot Gris without too much winemaking trickery. A delicately perfumed nose of honeysuckle, hibiscus and pear leads to a palate that is textural yet refreshing, expressing the variety's gentle floral and orchard fruit characters. A touch of bitterness at the finish distracts slightly, but overall this is a solid bottling of this style from a sensitive producer.

Moist underbrush, woodland berry, blue flower and dark culinary spice aromas delicately guide the nose. The poised, ethereal palate offers succulent sour cherry, coffee bean and a hint of clove while supple tannins and firm acidity offer lithe support. Drink through 2021.

wine_name: McIntyre Vineyards 2007 Estate Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
desc: Starts out very full-bodied and rich, almost too heavy for Pinot Noir. Then the acids kick in to accent the silky texture, and you know it's a ripe, ageable Pinot Noir. With deep flavors of raspberries, cherries, red currants, licorice, cocoa and peppery spices, it should develop well over the next 4–6 years.
Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Château Lagrézette 2019 Roseberry Malbec Rosé (Côtes du Lot)
desc: An attractive fruity wine with a bite of pepper, this is poised between soft and crisp. Its bright acidity and raspberry fruitiness are just right. It's ready to drink.
Appellation: Côtes du Lot, Southwest France, France

wine_name: Cuda Ridge Wines 2012 Cabernet Franc (Livermore Valley)
desc: Delicious, rich black cherry aromas lead to a very firm and moderately tannic texture and medium to full body that frames abundant fruit flavors. It's mouthwatering, intense and complex, but is still wound up tight, so it's best to drink after 2016.
Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Unusual aromas of anise, peanut shell, orange peel, medicine cabinet and fruit leather lead to medium-bodied fruit flavors. It shows a pleasantly restrained styling.
Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Red-fruit aromas lead to a softly textured wine. With just a touch of smokiness coupled with acidity, the wine's youth is still apparent, ready to age further. The aftertaste is juicy and full of perfumed raspberry flavors. Drink from early 2020.

wine_name: Silver Thread 2012 Doyle East Seneca Vineyard Riesling (Seneca Lake)
desc: Whiffs of smoke and dust add a savory tone to delicate flavors of apple and honeydew rind on this dry, zesty wine. It's medium bodied on the palate with refreshing lemon-lime acidity.
Appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US

wine_name: La Font du Vent 2005 Notre Passion Red (Côtes du Rhône Villages)
desc: Run by the Gonnet family of Font de Michelle in Châteauneuf-du-Pape, this is a wonderfully supple, ready-to-drink Côtes-du-Rhône that's more charming than big and hulking. Sandalwood, perfume and spice aromas lead into cherry-raspberry fruit backed by dusty, earthy notes and layers of spice.
Appellation: Côtes du Rhône Villages, Rhône Valley, France

wine_name: Sbragia 2007 Home Ranch Chardonnay (Dry Creek Valley)
desc: There's something rustic and spicy and earthy about Dry Creek Chardonnays, but Ed Sbragia manages to lift this wine into opulence. It's pretty oaky, yet the vanilla and honey flavors marry perfectly with the pineapple and pear fruit to produce a wine of great attraction.
Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US

desc: As its inviting name suggests, Buon Appetito will whet your appetite for hearty pasta with tomato sauce or even pizza. This fruit forward wine offers aromas of ripe cherry and blackberry with some green tones of dried herb at the back.
Here's a dry, tannic Merlot that's fine with burgers, barbecued steaks and other comfort foods that require a full-bodied red. With currant and cherry flavors, it's a good buy at this price.
Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Floral and honey-like aromas lead to very sweet flavors of apricot and peach in this medium-bodied wine. A good choice for friends that only drink sweet, or with your dessert.
Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US

desc: Spicy, with a hint of mint, this deftly integrated, late-release wine brings rhubarb and raspberry fruit into place. There's enough acidity to complement a nice, fatty piece of salmon, with a light streak of dried herbs running through the finish. It's drinking well, at or near its peak.

This assertive wine has spicy notes of chocolate, mulberry and oak on the nose, and ripe berry and clove flavors on the palate. The mouthfeel is full and round. The wine is rich and balanced but needs some time.

Ripe, open, apricot and pineapple fruit flavors suffuse this open, generous wine. This is an easy appellation to appreciate, with citrus tastes and vanilla giving a sharp point to the more flattering fruits. Drink now, or keep for another year. Imported by Dreyfus, Ashby & Co.

This fragrant, foaming dessert wine opens with aromas of yellow stone fruit, chopped herb and a floral note of jasmine. The rich, bright palate doles out apricot, yellow peach, grilled sage and candied nectarine zest alongside a delicate mousse and fresh acidity.

wine_name: In Re 2010 You be the judge! Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
desc: Sanguine in cedar, pencil lead and tea, this wine's elegant opening gives way to ripe black fruit and thick, burly tannins. The finish is marked in vanilla oak and a taste of cigar.

wine_name: Boheme 2013 Stuller Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
desc: From a beautifully cool coastal spot dotted in redwoods, this medium-bodied wine shows struggle in its tight layering of acidity and vibrantly fresh blueberry and black tea, Chewy in texture, still-resolving tannin and oak give way to a succulence that's just beginning to be revealed.

wine_name: João Teodosio Matos Barbosa 2007 Ninfa Escolha Red (Tejo)
desc: With some Syrah in the blend, the wine has a fine perfumed character. The fruit is stylish, with juicy blackberry flavors, laced with coffee, spicy toast, dusty tannins and delicious acidity. To age over 5–6 years.

wine_name: Papapietro Perry 2003 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
desc: The winery's basic appellation wine is full-bodied and heavy, showing very ripe berry, cherry and mocha flavors. It's almost like Syrah in weight, except for the silky, fine tannins.
Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US

desc: Delicate tangerine and yellow peach flavors are layered in smoke and dusty slate in this sprightly off-dry Riesling. It's a light-footed, piercing wine anchored by nervous lemon-lime acidity. The finish is long and lean, accented by a touch of dried herb.

wine_name: Cantalici L'Antica Fornace di Ridolfo 2013  Chianti Classico
desc: Aromas of coconut, toast, oak-driven spice and a whiff of prune lead the nose. The aromas carry over to the rather diluted, lean palate along with sour cherry and roasted coffee bean. Astringent, fleeting tannins give it an abrupt close.

Alluring aromas of ripe peach, grapefruit and lemon lead this stylish white. The wine offers integrated flavors of spicy citrus and lemon peel backed by a sea-salt salinity. Balanced and brisk but full of flavor, it's a great example of the elegance of this variety.
Ripe pear is supported by slight citrus on the nose. The mild palate picks up on the pear and lemon ripeness but defines this both with pithy and zesty notes on the slender, fresh and dry palate.

wine_name: Laurel Glen 1999 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma Mountain)
desc: This is the first commercial reserve wine Patrick Campbell has released in more than 20 years of winemaking, and it is indeed something special. Young and dense now, with firm tannins and acidity, and a richly explosive, meaty core of blackcurrant and cassis fruit. Completely authoritative. Campbell is at the top of his game with this marvelous, ageworthy wine. Drinkable now, but best aged through the decade.
94–96. Barrel Sample. This wine is rich yet finely balanced. The acidity and the tannins are well integrated with the beautiful black currant flavor. Overall, this fine wine promises a bright future.

wine_name: Lobo 2014 Wulff Vineyard Pinot Noir (Napa Valley)
desc: Stemmy earth and forest floor dominate on the nose of this funky wine, which offers sizable oak and a touch of leather. Big boned and concentrated, it finishes in black pepper and cardamom.

Good, young Aussie Shiraz. What more needs to be said? It's jammy and fruity, stuffed with blackberry, loganberry and black cherry flavors that come across dry and tannic. The tannins and considerable acidity make it a bit rough in the mouth—try it with rich foods.
Appellation: New South Wales, New South Wales, Australia

wine_name: Page Springs 2011 Vino del Barrio Red (Cochise County)
desc: A scent of desiccated black fruit hits the nose first, followed by touches of herbal tea and dark cherry. A wild blend of Syrah, Petite Sirah, Tempranillo, Alicante and Mourvèdre, this has a concentrated palate and tonic acidity.
Review unavailable at this time

wine_name: J. Christopher 2013 Dundee Hills Cuvée Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)
desc: This barrel selection evokes the AVA's black-cherry fruit character nicely, keeping it lively and balanced, with excellent depth. Tasting the wine is like gazing into a deep pool; the flavors keep pushing further into the finish. Streaks of coffee and milk chocolate are in the mix, but it's the excellent fruit that captures your attention and holds it.
Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: Black berry, fig, cocoa and sweet cigar spice start you off on the nose of this wine. The soft and silky mouth offers more of the same, with a lingering sweet spice and creamy vanilla flavor that stays through the finish. Drink now.
Impeccably dry with a brisk, sprightly character, this lime-inflected Riesling is elegant on the palate with a wet-stone minerality and hints of smoke and pressed apples on the finish.
Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US

wine_name: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2014 Les Rugiens Premier Cru  (Pommard)
desc: This wine is rich, firmly structured while also full of dense black fruits. It comes from one of the top premier-cru vineyards in the appellation, well situated halfway up the slope, facing east. The wine will develop slowly as the ripe fruit comes through the structure. Drink from 2021.

From one of the rare estates in Saint-Julien that is not a classed growth, this wine has many of the same perfumed, elegant characteristics as its illustrious neighbors. Restrained tannins show well against the ripe black-currant fruit and spice from new-wood aging. Drink this wine from 2024.

A high-quality Sauvignon Blanc, maybe one of the better ones of the year. Has a nice balance of grassy, citrus flavors and riper ones of apples and peaches. Especially notable for the lush, distinguished tannins and acids you expect from this appellation.

With Anselmo Mendes, the Vinho Verde master, as consultant, this is a coastal Lisboa wine that has plenty of the crisp texture that comes from the Alvarinho in the blend. There is a perfumed touch from Viognier, giving the wine crispness as well as a rich background. Drink this wine from 2018.
This is a good go-to red to stock up on. Gobs of tasty fruit flavors make it delicious. The texture is velvety, the acid and tannin are balanced, and the body is lush but not too full.

wine_name: Rivera de Castilla 2007 Tempranillo (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León)
desc: Smells more meaty and leathery than you might expect for a basic, young Tempranillo. But enough berry fruit sneaks through to make it a solid but narrow wine driven by red plum and other standard red-fruit flavors. Finishes fresh but lean.
Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León, Northern Spain, Spain

wine_name: André Guichot 2010 La Maladière Premier Cru  (Santenay)
desc: This is an attractively structured wine, with ripe strawberry and smoky wood flavors. The fruit continues through to the soft finish, which is laced with acidity and a firm tannic core.
Very candy-flavored wine, the color vivid pink and the flavors just as garish, with strawberry sweetness, a touch of caramel balanced with lemon sherbet acidity. Screwcap.

wine_name: Rockledge Vineyards 2003 The Rocks Cabernet Sauvignon (St. Helena)
desc: More tannic than Rockledge's regular '03 Cab, this wine is also more concentrated in black currant fruit, and seems oakier, too. It has that elusive quality of importance, hard to define but so obvious in the mouth. Rich, luscious and on the soft side, it's a gorgeous wine, drinkable now and with the balance to ride smoothly for ten years or longer.

wine_name: Columbia Crest 2012 H3 Cabernet Sauvignon (Horse Heaven Hills)
desc: Varietal notes of cherry, black currant and dried herbs accented by barrel notes of milk chocolate and vanilla. It's medium bodied, showing some grit to the tannins.
Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

wine_name: Mas Foraster 2013 Josep Foraster Macabeu Macabeo (Conca de Barberà)
desc: Almondy in color, with bready, drawn aromas of mustard and pithy citrus, this feels flat and chunky. Flavors of almond skins and pithy white fruits finish with a note of orange peel.

wine_name: Il Feuduccio Di S. Maria D'Orni 2015  Montepulciano d'Abruzzo
desc: A well-formed nose of tart red berries, smoke, fresh herbs and tobacco starts this off. Firmly medium in weight, the palate is well structured, offering integrated tannins and juicy acidity that house flavors of ripe cherry and currant. A dusting of herbs and smoke linger on the finish.
Winery: Il Feuduccio Di S. Maria D'Orni

desc: In the Waipara Valley, north of Christchurch, this Sauvignon Blanc ticks many of the country's typical style boxes. It's fragrant and zippy, with heady fruit-bowl aromas of lemon rind, peach, guava and pineapple along with a touch of green bell pepper—a refreshing summer sipper.

Winemaker Denis Malbec has created a brilliantly delicious, crisp, dry yet richly textured version of the variety that opens with golden honey, dried apricot and lychee on the nose and mouth. Very minerally, the wine has a steely finish with smoky, oaky edges.
Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US

wine_name: Domaine Laroche 2013 Premier Cru La Chantrerie  (Chablis)
desc: This blend from small parcels in different premier cru vineyards has a touch of wood with an almost chalky texture. Ripe yellow fruits give it a rich, rounded character. Delicious, refreshing acidity adds the balance the wine needs. Still textured, it needs to age, so drink from 2017.

Made with 90% Sangiovese and 10% Merlot, this medium-bodied red has aromas suggesting underbrush, red plum and a whiff of tobacco leaf. The round palate offers black cherry, clove and a hint of thyme alongside supple tannins. Drink through 2019.

wine_name: Challen 2016 Lindsay's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
desc: This wine has bones to last at least a decade, and needs a bit more time to come together. Aromas of rich black cherry, hickory, chiseled slate and loamy soil are more mineral than fruit-driven. The palate is also powered by slate and gravel, with polished but firm structure and a steadily rising acidity that cuts through the dark fruits. Drink 2020–2031.
Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Powerful and complex, this shows the density that comes from Chardonnay sourced on the hill of Corton. The rich tropical-fruit flavors are structured, which gives this wine strong aging potential. Keep it for at least six years.

wine_name: Collina San Ponzio 2016 Bric dei Pittatori  (Barbera d'Alba)
desc: Aromas of ripe black cherry, blackberry and clove lead the nose. The aromas carry over to the juicy, fruity palate, together with a white-pepper note alongside bright acidity.

wine_name: Yardstick 2010 Ruth's Reach Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
desc: Made by the veteran winemaker Nick Goldschmidt, this is a good Cabernet showing characteristic Napa qualities. It's dry and smooth in tannins, with cassis, blackberry and oak flavors. ?Overripe in style, it has a slightly raisined feel.
Round, soft and slightly sweet-tasting, this wine offers a mouthful of vanilla-accented grape and black cherry flavors. Sure it finishes short, but look at the price. Best Buy.

Saline and sea breeze lend refreshing, nautical appeal to this elegant unoaked Chardonnay. It's plush and plump in mouthfeel but anchored by bracing lemon, tangerine and grapefruit flavors. Drink now through 2020.
Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US

desc: Chewing gum aromas are simple and mild, while this blend of Garnacha and Viura feels lean and punchy. Yeasty flavors offer only a touch of fruit, while this is fresh and healthy but bland on the finish.

wine_name: Château Bellevue 2012 Cuvée Vieilles Vignes  (Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux)
desc: Old vines and wood aging have given this wine rich concentration. It is smoky, spicy and still firm with tannins. The structure is filling out with the blackberry fruits and acidity. The wine will be ready to drink from 2017.
Appellation: Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France

desc: In most years, Alabaster blows you away with its power, concentration and depth of flavors. In 2014, a mediocre year in much of Northern Spain, this is still excellent. Blackberry, cassis and creosote aromas are toasty, while this is flush in feel and severely tannic. Blackberry, mocha and coffee flavors finish with creamy oak and chocolate notes along with meaty tannins. Only 100 cases produced; drink through 2030.

This impressively dark and smooth Shiraz has a taut black fruit and licorice bouquet. Very smooth and supple on the palate, it offers rich blackcurrant, cassis and chocolate flavors. Fine, even tannins on the long finish close this very well structured, nicely integrated wine that should improve with two to four years cellaring.

This steep vineyard produces a particularly rich style of Chablis because of its excellent exposure. This wine exemplifies this. It is warm, and rounded, with superrich yellow fruits, almost tropical. Underlying it all is a structure derived from green plum skin flavors.

wine_name: J. Rickards 2011 1908 Brignole Vineyard Old Vine Zinfandel (Alexander Valley)
desc: A classic, old-style field blend best identified as Zinfandel, this heady red opens with perfumed baking spice and a tinge of black licorice. Soft, integrated tannins make it juicy and approachable in red and black berry, with robust but not distracting oaky tones.
This shows round, thick aromas of stone fruit and honeydew melon. The bouquet is sophisticated, and the mouthfeel is lean and fresh.

wine_name: Príncipe de Viana 2011 Edición Limitada Red (Navarra)
desc: Plum, tobacco and cheesy aromas register as spicy and rustic on the nose. A raw, hard-tannin palate offers herbal flavors of thyme and rosemary to go with chocolate and raspberry notes. Toasty oak, heat and length on the finish suggest that this may improve over the next five years.

Gentle red cherry fruit appears on the nose and swishes across the juicy palate where tannins and freshness provide a frame for all the cherry abundance. This majors on delicious fruit but comes with a lovely grip.

This admittedly oaky wine makes an attractive package of cedary, savory aromas and rich fruit flavors. It's playful on the nose, with rosemary and forest floor aromas, and almost-sweet Bing cherry flavors on the full-bodied and smooth palate.

wine_name: Terras de Alter 2018 Terra d'Alter VDL Verdelho (Alentejano)
desc: Lightly perfumed and attractively fruity, this is an apple and canteloupe flavored wine. Its acidity just brings out the ripeness of the fruit while also underlining the bright aftertaste.

Though not quite as concentrated as the ripe, super-saturated 2005 Chardonnay, this has a similar mix of tropical and stone fruits, wrapped in thick, buttery, oaky barrel flavors. It's soft and round, already quite evolved, but helped out by the higher acids of the vintage.
Appellation: Rattlesnake Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Like many 2005s from the northern Rhone, Colombo's Les Ruchets needs time. The tannins dominate the mouth right now, but the black olive and peppered-meat nuances win out in the end, adding depth to tarry, leathery notes and plummy fruit. Try after 2015.

wine_name: Project M 2018 Personify Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
desc: Lovely fruit is the mainstay here, a tangy mix of blueberry, blackberry and black cherry in equal proportions. The fruit is set nicely against polished but unintrusive tannins, and a hint of black olive permeates the finish. All in all, it is a most compelling and delicious wine.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: Blackberry-sauce and cocoa-dust aromas meet with slightly sour herbs and fennel on the nose of this bottling. Ripe blackberry-sorbet flavors are dusted in more dank herbs on the palate.
Appellation: Carmel Valley, Central Coast, California, US

desc: This classic Sancerre is a fresh, crisp, but intensely fruity wine that still tastes of young green fruits and currants. It has a fine depth of flavor, promising good development. Very crisp green apple flavors to finish. Imported by Vineyard Brands.

wine_name: Domaine Charles Frey 2011 Vieilles Vignes Riesling (Alsace)
desc: Straw gold in color, this is a fragrant, delicately aromatic wine. Made from organic fruit, it has pure white fruit and mineral flavors that are cut with intense youthful acidity. It needs to develop, so wait to drink until 2016.

wine_name: Arbor Brook 2009 Croft Vineyard Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)
desc: Bright and spicy, this is Pinot Gris with a bit of the grassy bite of a Loire Valley Sauvignon Blanc. Racy and loaded with grapefruit and pineapple flavors, this lingers lazily through a refreshing, acid-driven finish that invites further sipping.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: 92–94. Barrel Sample. This is a ripe and smoky wine that has firm, dry tannins. It has a rich structure that brings out ripe plum and berry fruits. The final feel is round and generous.

wine_name: Hanna 2006 Bismark Mountain Vineyard Zinfandel (Sonoma Valley)
desc: Despite the “valley” appellation, this is one of the highest elevation vineyards in Sonoma County. It's a dense, tannic, concentrated wine, with a deep core of black currants, black pepper and chocolate. Zinfanatics will absolutely love it, but it's very high in alcohol, almost Port-like, although the finish is absolutely dry.

wine_name: Château Beauchêne 2003 Grande Réserve Red (Côtes du Rhône)
desc: A classic blend of southern Rhône grapes—Grenache, Syrah, Cinsault and Carignan—this reflects the hot 2003 vintage but still manages to keep some restraint. The tannins hold the juicy, red berry fruit flavors together, while dry wood notes add complexity.
Appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France

desc: An interesting, complex wine with the peppery aroma of a fine Northern Rhône. But the softness and forward fruit are all California. Tastes like blackberry tea with a shot of cassis followed by a shot of cocoa. Sweet oak is there, too.
This medium-sweet wine is hugely spicy and rich. It has lychee, tropical fruit and vanilla flavors, yielding a wine that is a meal on its own. Drink now.

Moderate in oak and well-structured, this estate-grown wine is subdued and classy, with defined layers of green olive, juicy apple and lemongrass, a tiny hint of jalapeño adding a touch of spice. Food-friendly, it'll complement a versatile range of dishes.

Black pepper scents meet very ripe berry and cherry aromas in this full-bodied, flavorful wine. It has broad texture, moderate tannins and acidity, and lots of concentration. Saturated with fruit, its ripness keeps unfolding on the finish.
Try this as an alternative to Merlot or Pinot Noir. Well balanced and medium bodied, it has light and appetizing cherry and strawberry flavors and a smooth mouthfeel.

Starts out sulfury, then turns simple in structure and semi-sweet in flavor, with sugary LifeSaver candy raspberry and cherry flavors. The acidity that's always associated with the variety is pleasantly scouring.
Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Bodega Cuarto Dominio 2015 Chento Vineyard Selection Malbec (Mendoza)
desc: Foxy plum and berry aromas include notes of tobacco and moss. This feels grabby and acidic, with minor structural gaps. Herbal plum and black-fruit flavors finish oaky, salty and with rubbery tannins. Give this more time and it may improve. Drink through 2021.

wine_name: Heron 2007 Pinot Noir (Vin de Pays de la Méditerranée)
desc: The aromas are a touch on the funky side with notes of mushy compost pile and rotting cherries. The mouth shows more sour red fruit and rhubarb flavors. Decent if you don't mind strong leafy/foliage characteristics.
Appellation: Vin de Pays de la Méditerranée, France Other, France

desc: A new concept from this Aÿ-based producer, this wine showcases pure Pinot Noir from some of its finest parcels. The wine has weight and richness while not losing sight of elegance. The fruit is just beginning to mature, showing a crisp texture while promising a broader vision in the future. Drink from 2021.

This is soft and lightly scented with citrus. Aromas of lemon peel precede light flavors of citrus and green apple. It's a simple, quaffable white wine, with a bit of Riesling and Viognier in the blend.
Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Red fruit and spice aromas lead the bouquet of this wine. The palate is a bit subdued, but reveals red cherry and strawberry flavors alongside accents of white pepper. There's a subtle warmth to the midpalate.
Stewed plum, exotic spices and a whiff of vanilla form the nose. The solid, chewy palate evokes mature Marasca cherry, mocha and licorice alongside firm tannins. Drink 2021–2027.

wine_name: D'Arenberg 2016 The Twenty Eight Road Mourvèdre (McLaren Vale)
desc: D'Arenberg's big reds can often be a bargain, especially compared with some of the Barossa blockbusters. This 100% Mourverdré (from the family's over 100-year-old bush vines) is an excellent example of value. Simultaneously classic McLaren Vale and classic d'Arenberg, this wine bursts from the glass with cherries, cedar, mint chocolate, cola and heaps of earthy spice. The fleshy tangy fruit on the palate is gripped by powerful, dusty tannins. This big but balanced wine needs a decanter and protein now or time in the cellar. Drink now–2029.

There's plenty to chew on on the aromas, with notes of pear, citrus, strawberry and cream. Broad, heavy feeling strawberry flavors. It gets a bit bogged down through the middle, but the acid picks it back up.
Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Perfumed and elegant, this has soft tannins to balance the red-berry flavors. Depth and concentration come from the rich fruitiness, acidity and the firm, dry core. The wine will be at its best from 2022.

Starts out round and red fruited before turning more herbal and raw with air. The palate is thick and rugged, with green-inflected strawberry and raspberry flavors. Quick, minty tasting and gritty on the finish.

While the name means “burnt,” it really refers to the southern exposure of this warm vineyard. Wood aged in new barrels, this wine has a toasty character that is well balanced by the rich fruits. Acidity and a mineral texture give this wine aging potential. Drink from 2017.

wine_name: Les Vignerons du Castelas 2017 Rosé (Côtes du Rhône)
desc: Bright red cherry, raspberry and watermelon flavors abound in this juicy, concentrated dry rosé. It's gorgeously fruity and forward but nuanced, too, accented by hints of bramble, thyme and sage. Full bodied yet freshly balanced, it boasts a long, pristine finish.
Appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France

desc: Initially, it seems somewhat foursquare, with sharp corners, but that is from its youth, and with the black plum fruit flavors, there is plenty of ripeness and balance to come yet.

wine_name: Iron Horse 2016 Deer Gate Pinot Noir (Green Valley)
desc: This is a meaty and savory wine from the Green Valley producer, textured in a delicate midpalate that picks up force as it goes. A substantial concentration of Asian spice seasons baked plum and dark cherry, with a smoky twinge to the oak.

Here is Auxerrois at its very best, fragrant with orange, quince and honey, and lively with lemon-lime and pink grapefruit on the palate. The final impression—of stone and spice—leaves you craving that next sip.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: Combining estate grapes from both Roberts Road and Green Acres vineyards, this showcases the coast well in its firmness of structure and high-toned acidity. Starting off somewhat reduced on the nose, it opens slowly to reveal layers of Meyer lemon, melon and green apple, with a richer back note of baked peach.

wine_name: Cave de Kientzheim-Kaysersberg 2012 Anne de K Schlossberg Grand Cru Riesling (Alsace)
desc: With its firm structure and strongly steely tendencies, this wine will repay aging. Orange citrus is woven into the texture of the wine, showing acidity and a taut, tangy aftertaste. It will need time to come together, so drink from 2018.
Designation: Anne de K Schlossberg Grand Cru

desc: Made entirely with Pinot Nero grapes cultivated according to certified biodynamic farming methods, this gorgeous sparkler offers delicate scents of wild red berry, baking spice and bread dough and grilled herb. The vibrant, bone-dry and delicious palate is loaded with finesse, delivering juicy strawberry, pomegranate, citrus zest and baking spice. Fresh acidity and a polished, foaming mousse lend balance and finesse.
An earthy hint comes with the bright lemon flavors of this dry, tart wine. The palate reveals a glimpse of riper fruit but lime freshness rules. It finishes totally clean.

wine_name: Epoch 2015 Authenticity Red (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)
desc: Hearty and savory aromas of roasted meat, strong black cherry and char show on the nose of this blend of 81% Syrah and 19% Mourvèdre. It's thick, rich and deep with flavors of roasted black currant, smoked fig and coffee on the palate, where fine-grained tannins stand up toward the finish.
Appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Ledgewood Creek 2007 Three Clone Estate Grown Chardonnay (Suisun Valley)
desc: Overtly sweet, like sugared peach and lemon juice, fortunately balanced with crisp acidity. If you like that off-dry taste, it's for you.
Appellation: Suisun Valley, North Coast, California, US

desc: Ripe pineapple, juicy peach and Key lime flavors fill the medium-weight mouth, while a soft accent of peach pit develops on the finish. Balanced and straightforward; drink now.
This ripe, fruity wine has attractive acidity that's balanced with yellow fruit and apple notes. It shows a bright character, with some good intensity of flavor and a crisp, refreshing finish.

wine_name: Domaine de la Pousse d'Or 2002 Volnay Premier cru Clos de la Bousse d'Or  (Volnay)
desc: Delicious structured fruit with aromas of ripe dark plums. The big tannins are well balanced with acidity and solid black fruits. Coffee and acidity give complexity.
Designation: Volnay Premier cru Clos de la Bousse d'Or

wine_name: Wolff 2006 Dijon Clones Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)
desc: A little raw and simple, with cherry-cola and wintergreen flavors that finish dry and spicy.
Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Cave de Ribeauvillé 2010 Gloeckelberg Grand Cru Pinot Gris (Alsace)
desc: The nose already promises both texture and ripeness with its combined aroma of russet pear peel and juicy pear flesh. The palate only adds to the juicy richness with a good dollop of residual sweetness, boosting all of the pear fruit. This is countered by wonderful lemon drop freshness. The plump but shapely palate is utterly concentrated and aromas of candle wax and honeycomb show that this has just begun to evolve. While the finish has distinct sweetness, it is balanced by 2010's glorious freshness. Lovely now, especially alongside cheese or hot Asian spice, but sure to develop further. Drink 2017–2030.

wine_name: Errazuriz 2009 Viñedo Chadwick Cabernet Sauvignon (Maipo Valley)
desc: Initially this smells reductive and like horseradish, although with airing it moves on to aromas of pepper and berry. Citrusy acidity gives zest to what is otherwise a creamy-feeling red. Flavors of cassis, berry and brown sugar lead to a long, baked-tasting finish.

wine_name: Drei Donà Tenuta La Palazza 2010 Notturno Sangiovese (Forlì)
desc: Notturno is an easy-drinking Sangiovese that delivers ripe fruit, prune and a dark garnet color. There's a darker, flatter and bolder quality to the grape farmed in the Forlì area of Emilia-Romagna compared to the same grape in Tuscany.

wine_name: Massimo Daldin 2015  Vernaccia di San Gimignano
desc: Here's a bright wine that opens with aromas of white field flowers, pears and a hint of nut. The straightforward palate offers yellow apple and a hint of bitter almond alongside fresh acidity.
Appellation: Vernaccia di San Gimignano, Tuscany, Italy

desc: This robust and classically rustic Primitivo tastes of dark cherry and just-picked brambly blackberry. A balanced mountain-grown wine, it has a wall of spice around its core, with elements of cinnamon and pepper, finished off by a refreshing twist of mint.
Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US

wine_name: Domaine Emmanuel Dampt 2018 Fouchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)
desc: A hint of sun-dried hayflowers gives aromatic lift to the nose of this wine. The palate comes in with freshness and poise, lending definition to ripe lemon notes on the palate. A concentrated, chalky backdrop reverberates with lemon freshness.

This shows why Walla Walla has such a fine reputation for Syrah. There's definition, cut and grace to this wine; it's got style. The fruit is tart and bracing, set against steely mineral and composted earth. It hints at other, more Rhône-ish flavors also, and it's a wine that you want to cellar to see where it goes. This is definitely the star of the show among Watermill's debut releases.
Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US

wine_name: Reichsgraf von Kesselstatt 2016 Graach Josephshöfer Trocken GG Riesling (Mosel)
desc: While the nose is intensely honeyed and floral, there's a steely mineral intensity on the palate of this elegant, dry Riesling. Pristine white grapefruit, lime and gooseberry flavors are invigorating and tart but fall on the palate in creamy, expansive layers. It's an impeccably balanced wine with a long, honed finish.

The black cherry fruit is accented by soy, menthol and olive notes on the nose in this polished but reserved wine. Medium- weight and evenly balanced, it's very dark on the palate, with espresso, chocolate and even a toasted sesame note showing. Closes quite dry with black licorice and mineral-chalk elements.

This immediately attractive and fruity wine takes its name from the church next to the winery. It is soft with ripe white fruits that are cut by citrus, spice and vanilla flavors. Open and easy, it will be ready to drink from late 2018.

wine_name: Pierre Sparr 2013 Mambourg Grand Cru Gewurztraminer (Alsace)
desc: Sweet, ripe and honeyed, this full wine has good depth of flavor as well as concentrated spiciness. It's still very young, needing to age to bring out more of its texture and richness. Drink from 2017.

wine_name: Rancho Sisquoc 2009 Flood Family Vineyards Malbec (Santa Barbara County)
desc: A dark, brooding, tannic young wine that actually smells like the grilled steak it should accompany. Blackberry and earth flavors surface on the palate, made brisk with acidity.
Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Here's one for the cellar. It's an intense, massively concentrated wine, packed with blackberry, black currant, dark chocolate and crême de cassis flavors. If that sounds delicious, it is, and the tannins are as fine and complicated as Napa gets. So tasty now, you can drink it with a great steak, and should easily develop bottle complexity over the next 8–10 years, perhaps much longer.

wine_name: Cave Spring 2017 CSV Cave Spring Vineyard Riesling (Beamsville Bench)
desc: Produced from vines approaching 45 years of age, this reserve-level effort is simply extraordinary. It's layered thickly with ripe tree fruits, peach in particular, along with citrus, melon and papaya. Perfectly framed with refreshing minerality derived from limestone soils, along with well-tempered skin flavors, this belongs among the very finest New World expressions of Riesling.

Butterflies dance across the label of this Niven Family wine from their Paragon Vineyard, but it packs a flavorful punch too. Aromas of lime juice drizzled on apples, honeysuckle and a bit of struck match lead into broad flavors of cooked apples and chalk, all held together by lemony zest. It's pretty on the label and in the glass.
Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US

desc: A screaming deal, this wine shows a nice blend of pencil lead, strawberries, peppercorn, oregano and chaparral scrub on the nose. The palate offers plenty of mocha and herbs including oregano and thyme, alongside elderberry and boysenberry fruit. It has enough tannic structure to notice but not enough to get in the way.
Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US

desc: Aromas of citrus, white stone fruit and a vegetal hint suggesting tomato leaf lead the way. The racy palate offers grapefruit, pineapple, fresh white peach and flinty mineral while a pleasantly bitter note closes the finish.

wine_name: Grosgrain 2019 Philips Vineyard Albariño (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
desc: Newcomer Grosgrain is quickly making a name for itself with wines like this. Primarily fermented and aged in concrete egg, with the rest in neutral barrel and stainless steel, its bright compellingly fresh aromas of tangerine, citrus peel and melon are followed by full-feeling, lively, lemony flavors, with racy acidity.
Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: Awkward in the mouth, with hard-edged tannins and cutting acidity that interferes with the berry, cherry, currant and spice flavors. This old-fashioned wine could mellow over the years, without gaining complexity.
Appellation: Calaveras County, Sierra Foothills, California, US

wine_name: Tenute del Cerro 2012 Riserva  (Vino Nobile di Montepulciano)
desc: Subtle oak, underbrush and leather aromas come together in this tart, astringent red. The palate offers sour cherry, orange zest, toast and sage flavors, framed by raspy tannins.
Appellation: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy

wine_name: Domaine Laroche 2012 Les Beauroys Premier Cru  (Chablis)
desc: This ripe and spicy wine is full-bodied and structured. Apples and yellow fruits push the wine forward with balanced acidity and a more tense background. It can be drunk now, although it will be better from 2016.

wine_name: Santa Julia 2014 Reserva Mountain Blend Malbec-Cabernet Franc (Uco Valley)
desc: Medicinal, earthy aromas of cherry, raspberry and plum are encouraging. This blend of Malbec and Cab Franc is tight and sinewy, with good acidity. Cherry, plum and chocolate flavors rest comfortably in front of a ripe, full finish.

Here is a ripe, full-flavored Cabernet that clocks in at a moderate 12.5% alcohol. The blend includes 10% Merlot and 15% Cabernet Franc. Surely a great strength of  cool-climate, Yakima Valley Cabernet is its ability to obtain ripe, naturally tart, mixed fruit flavors, and avoid joining the syrupy, jammy, hedonistic crowd. What's here are pure varietal flavors of blackberry and cassis, just lightly kissed with oak.
Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US

desc: This 113-acre estate has been owned for three generations by the Pagès family. Rich tannins contrast with the spicy, toasty flavor that will soften into the ripe black-currant fruits. Drink this wine from 2022.

Beautifully pure and aromatic notes of green pear, lemon peel and green spring herbs like tarragon and chervil play on the nose of this wine. The palate shows similar fruity, fresh and lively charm. Very refreshing.

wine_name: Belle Made For You NV Chardonnay (Vin de France)
desc: This wine is light, fresh and fruity, just hinting at yellow fruits and with a sweet aftertaste. Drink immediately.
Appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France

wine_name: Santa Rita 2008 Reserva Cabernet Sauvignon (Maipo Valley)
desc: Nice and ripe, with light whiffs of olive and herbs and strong berry fruit aromas. The palate is pure Maipo, meaning it blends herbal notes with black fruits, especially cassis. Firm in structure, stout on the finish, and ends with a hint of chocolate.

For Esporão's winemaker, Australian David Baverstock, this Syrah must seem like a wine from home. He makes a rich, meaty wine, but it has more structure than a New World version, balancing acidity and firm, dry tannins against the sweetness of the fruit. Great to drink, but could age. Imported by Aidil Wines & Liquor Inc.

wine_name: Occasio 2010 Thatcher Bay Vineyard Merlot (Livermore Valley)
desc: This is a muscular Merlot, exotic in cinnamon/cardamom spice that's otherwise soft, structured and complex. The tannins are most pronounced on the finish and need time to further integrate, but make the wine long-lasting in leathery cassis and tobacco flavor.
Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Cayuse 2011 Camaspelo Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (OR))
desc: Camaspelo is mostly Cabernet Sauvignon, blended with 20% Merlot. The fruit shines through brightly in this cooler vintage, black cherry and plum with a saline minerality. The wine saw 40% new oak, perhaps for the last time, as Christophe Baron believes “the barrel is dead” and is moving to all-neutral, large format foudres, puncheons and concrete. Soft, supple and sensuous, this is a delicious wine drinking quite nicely already.
Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US

wine_name: Good Intentions 2018 Frankie Cabernet Franc (Mount Gambier)
desc: From a tiny, high altitude region near the border of Victoria, this naturally made Cab Franc is complex yet highly drinkable without a lick of funk. Black cherry-hued, it opens with notes of black olive, licorice, dark chocolate, damp earth and wild bramble berries. There's some power in the mouth but an ease, too, as though comfortable in its own skin, unforced by winemaking trickery; a flow of juicy brambly fruit, crystalline acidity, sinewy tannins and a mineral, sanguine note toward the finish. Drink now with wintery fare.
A harsh wine, with cutting acids and a thin flavor of raspberry candy.

wine_name: Daou 2012 Chemin de Fleurs White (Paso Robles)
desc: This blend of Grenache Blanc, Roussanne and Viognier is rich and ripe with tropical fruit, orange, apricot, lime and vanilla flavors. Crisp acidity balances it out, but it's still a ripe wine that will pair well with Asian fare that's slightly sweet and spicy.
Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US

wine_name: Fratelli Berlucchi 2009 Casa delle Colonne Brut Riserva  (Franciacorta)
desc: This opens with aromas of bread crust, ripe orchard fruit and a citrusy note. The creamy palate offers baked yellow apple, vanilla and toasted hazelnut alongside a soft perlage.

wine_name: Ken Wright 2008 Freedom Hill Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
desc: This is a different style than past vintages of Freedom Hill, with less tannin and alcohol. Cranberry fruit flavors are augmented with some pretty whiffs of incense, but it feels a bit simple in the mouth, and turns slightly chalky through the finish.
Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US

desc: Meaty, funky aromas raise questions about fruit quality. A tight, hard palate isn't much for complexity or structure, while this tastes of plum and rubber. A dry finish leaves a sense of heat.

wine_name: Bodegas Gutiérrez de la Vega 2012 Ulises Red (Spain)
desc: Rubbery, sulfuric aromas of scrambled eggs are gaseous and difficult to penetrate. This blend of 60% Giró and 40% Monastrell feels choppy, grabby and high in acidity. Flavors of rubbery plum and berry are tart and eggy, while the tannins are fierce on the finish.
This refreshing wine offers aromas of honeydew melon and guava. A palate-pleasing combination of green apple, nectarine and eucalyptus culminate in a mint-tinged finish.

Easygoing and nicely fruity, this medium-bodied wine will be great for casual occasions and people with varied tastes. It uses organic grapes and no added sulfites. The aroma exudes raspberry and strawberry while the flavors are cherry-like and verge on sweet.

wine_name: Cook's NV White Zinfandel Rosé Sparkling (California)
desc: Simple and short, with light cherry, citrus and herb notes.

wine_name: Charles Sohler et ses Fils NV Blanc de Blancs Sparkling (Crémant d'Alsace)
desc: Fresh lemon fruit and lime rind make for a bright, lively and refreshing nose on this wine. Frothy fizz on the palate intensifies this citric freshness but also boosts it with rather generous dosage. The finish is superfresh and off dry.

wine_name: Domaine le Bout du Lieu 2007 Orbe Noir  (Cahors)
desc: A very fine wine with some bottle age that has given the dense tannins a chance to integrate beautifully into its sweet fruit. There is a bitter chocolate edge that comes from the wood aging. It has a dark and very structured aftertaste.

This attempt at a Greek white made in a fatter, riper style is partially successful, yielding rich, honeyed aromas of beeswax and hints of peach and lemon that don't deliver quite as much length on the palate.
This is fresh and lively, with a black cherry core accented by hints of nutmeg, mint, carob and fig. It has both elegance and structure. Pair this with meat-filled ravioli or seasoned cheeses.
Appellation: Valpolicella Classico Superiore Ripasso, Veneto, Italy

desc: Not a typically fruity Grigio, this one relies more on spices and minerals to make a palate impression. Hints of almond and dried cinnamon start things off, followed by stony, mineral flavors backed by pears and allspice.
This simple Bordeaux blend opens with an attractive red berry-rhubarb and toast nose, but not much follows. It's lightweight and not amply fruited, closing tart with quite drying tannins.

This wine has aromas of raspberry with a touch of summer farm stand. Tannins are a bit strong, with flavors of cherry preserves, chocolate and eucalyptus. The finish is notable for its touches of mint.

wine_name: Feudi di San Gregorio 2008 Privilegio White (Campania)
desc: A luminous dessert blend of Fiano and Falanghina, Privilegio is an opulent and creamy wine with sweet tones of candied fruit, honey and white almond that last long on the palate. Pair this beauty with a platter of aged cheese and sweet marmalade.

wine_name: B Cellars 2016 Dutton Ranch Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
desc: Dark-golden color gives way to a rich, rounded exploration of baked apple, nutmeg and toasted oak in this well-made vineyard-designate. The creamier, concentrated tones are given a lift of freshness from persistent acidity.
Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
